number of helpful: 11 of 13 people (85%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 29, 2013
												Right now, there is nothing about The Stanley Parable that I don't hate.There are games built around a cohesive story with relatable characters, a satisfying dramatic arc and a worthwhile conclusion. This is not one of those games. The Stanley Parable is confusing and all-over-the-place, the main characters are inconsistent, sometimes depressingly shallow, other times infuriatingly opaque. The story spits on the ideals of internal logic.If a video game makes you want to stop playing video games, what does that say about it?The Stanley Parable dragged me into its tangled mass of content without much of a warning. During most of my time playing it, I had at best a vague idea of what was going on. And although it tried everything in its power to defeat me (at one point it was literally begging me to stop playing), I pressed on.The game is ruthless in its mission of deconstructing the concepts of video game narration. It draws back the curtain and exposes the man who pulls the strings. Or pushes the buttons, as it were. Am I able to simply go back to normal games with normal stories, pretend I didn't gaze into the abyss? I can only hope.I think I've come reasonably close to hearing everything that The Stanley Parable has to tell. Its attention to detail is impressive, the love and skill that went into it easily apparent. At times I felt like Sherlock Holmes, with my personal Moriarty always one tantalizing step ahead. Other times I felt a sense of true companionship when my friend and I forged ahead towards destiny. Yet other times I was confronted with a sadistic psychopath, a gentle father figure, or a petty, passive-agressive bystander.The Stanley Parable raises more questions than it answers. Fortunately they are the right kind of questions, the ones that keep you questioning yourself and the world around you rather than frustrate and paralyze you. I'm still relishing the afterglow, so my opinion may shift slightly when I've made more progress processing my experiences.Right now though, there is nothing about The Stanley Parable that I don't love.

content:
Posted: October 20, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is one of the most remarkable games I've ever played.It is a game about games. It's about the relationship between the player and the game and the interactivity that makes this medium unique.That's about as much as I can say about The Stanley Parable without giving anything away. There are no mechanics bound to your keyboard and mouse beyond move, look, open doors and push buttons. The central mechanic of the game is your choice and your perception of the game, incarnated as the Narrator.The game is essentially a choose your own adventure book, elevated to become something truly special by excellent writing, one of the endings features a profound paradox, and phenomenal delivery by the Narrator. The Stanley Parable is extremely clever, amusing and thought-provoking. An absolute must-buy, though I would recommend playing the demo first.<3

												Great game. The amount of detail put into the endings makes for a really entertaining game. It even has Easter eggs of other games such as Papers, Please, Payday and even Portal. (But most of the time, funny). Rating: 8.5/10 Recommendation: Yes

number of helpful: 12 of 16 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												The Stanley Parable is, no doubt, one of the strangest games I've ever played. Right when I saw it on steam I had no idea what to think. All it shows is a bunch of office cubicles and computers, and the discription, though interesting, didn't really help me decide whether to buy it or not. I almost gave it a pass, until I heard everyone and their grandmother going on about, "Have you played 'Stanley Parable? It's AMAZING!' It's hilarious! It make's you question your existance!" So I finally decided to give it a try when I saw it on sale. And...It's unbelievable. I never thought I could play something so hilarious, so drawing, so strangely thought provoking in my life. I honestly don't know where to begin because, and I know everyone whose reviewed this has said this but, I'm afraid I'll spoil something. I don't even want to upload any screenshots. Just trust everyone on this, this is a game that no one, I mean no one should pass up.Okay I'll give a little bit more detail, here's what I love best about it. Every joke works, I mean it. It has, what might be hundreds of jokes packed in there, and every one of them had me flinging my head back with laughter. A lot of the jokes are Fourth-wall jokes (and if you don't know what the Fourth-Wall is look it up on TVTropes.com), addressing the player directly. The game also likes to screw with you, but not in a scary way. As you progress the environment starts to change, sometimes drastically. To the point where you may throw your hands in the air and scream "What's happening!?" as I did at one point. The game may make you start to question reality as well...Look the point is stop reading this review and BUY THIS GAME! Every thing you've heard about it is true. All of it's Game of the Year nominations are well-deserved. GO NOW!

number of helpful: 13 of 18 people (72%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
												Play the demo to get a taste. Just get that out of the way.  And don't worry, the demo has almost none of the content of the actual game.  But it does give you a feel for what to expect.Now, look, I admit that "play the demo" may sound like a bit of a cop-out, but trust me, The Stanley Parable is unlike any game you've ever played. On the surface, it looks like you're just wandering around an office in an FPS where you can't shoot or jump.  And that's true.  But it's not a fair assessment.  The Stanley Parable is -- to employ an outdated and well-trodden expression -- "like a Choose Your Own Adventure on crack".  It's a game about choice.  Your coworkers have vanished, and you are tasked with finding out why.  Will you bother to discover where they went?  Or maybe you'll forge your own path.  But what consequences could there be for straying from the story?  What if compliance was actually...in your best interest?  Will you ever find the myriad secrets and endings tucked away?  Will you even go so far as to cheat to find them?!  (Seriously?!)The Stanley Parable has been a deeply memorable experience. It's a haunting, yet hilarious, unconventional journey.  For me, it is second only to Antichamber in my personal Top 10 list of great gaming experiences.(For those who have played the original, free HL2 mod of this game, it is WELL WORTH picking up this new retail version.  It looks amazing, and adds a ton of new material.  And you can finally thank the author with actual money.)

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is a biting, witty and satirical take on the current state of video-games. Their design and interaction mechanics, how they function to entice your progress (or impede) through the game's plot and enviornment. Throughout the game, there is a narrator who guides you through your curated experience, in certain points of conflict or 'choice' he tries to coerce you down the 'right' path. Whether you follow this disembodied voice or no is left up-to you but Galactic Cafe accepts a 'players' right of impositing their own 'choicesi/i]' in the game. The Parable has a minimalist soundtrack and soundscape which seek to complement the rather barren and sterile look of the game environment and the feeling of disconnect with the same. Overall The Stanley Parable is a wonderful look at how everything is right and wrong with the way games are presented to their audience, gamers and how we are stimulated to be kept in this circle. Also, you cannot jump and this game has an ADVENTURE LINE. You got to purchase the game just so you can follow that, YES! YES! You must.

												Again, after Gone Home, I'm here trying to understand if this is a game or not. Again, I really don't have an answer, at least not one that will satisfy everyone, all I can say is that I really enjoyed playing The Stanley Parable. It is fun to explore, more than  A LOT of "open world" games, it is fun to look at, it is fun to understand. The narrator is brilliant, the madness of the whole situation is hilarious. A game about choices whose first clear statement is that you don't have any... and still, you got multiple endings, a lot of crossroads to try, a lot of different explanations to what's happening. But only playing you'll understand that everything is kinda useless... or maybe not. I liked it. Thumbs up.

I can't tell you why because that would ruin it. Don't look it up online. Just buy it and play it blindly for the best experience. Trust me, it's worth it. The only thing I will say is that there are several endings, so be sure to play through the game like 5 to 10 times (It's worth it).Although I can't talk about things that are in the game, I can give you some tips to improve your experience.HELPFUL TIPS:DO NOT SKIP THE INTRO CUT SCENEJust don't.LISTEN TO THE NARRATORYou don't have to do what he says, but listen to what he has to say.GET THE DOOR 430 ACHIEVEMENT(After playing through the game a time or two)That's about it. Buy. Play. Enjoy. If you liked the review, please let me know by hitting the thumbs up button below. And as always, Happy Gaming!See my other reviews at http://steamcommunity.com/id/flinchmeister/recommended/

content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												This game starts as a walking-simulator in an office listening to a beautiful voice. The narrator wants to guide the player, and then starts to complain when the latter does not follow the rules. A love-hate relationship grows between the player and the narrator. The experience seems short but actually there are tons of branching paths (sometimes leading to different places and concepts), and the deeper themes of the game start to unravel. Choice and free will, a meta commentary on videogame narration and player agency, and so on.Very meta, very funny, each playthrough is short but sweet and got me excited to try new things and see how the narrator would react.

Product received for free
												The Stanley Parable is an experimental narrative-driven first person game. It is an exploration of choice, freedom, storytelling and reality, all examined through the lens of what it means to play a video game.- You will make a choice that does not matter- You will follow a story that has no end- You will play a game you cannot win...it's actually best if you don't know anything about it before you play it...The HD Remix of The Stanley Parable is a remodeled, remastered version of this unique title.I think this is not even a game, but in life someone told us to give us advice, and someone wants to scourge us, he brings a very deep meaning. 10/10

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 14, 2014
												One of the most clever, thought-provoking deconstruction of common video game narratives and tropes in recent years. This is not a typical video game in the most common sense. Instead, it is an effective vehicle for some of the most important subjects pertaining to video games and their narrative. Where Dear Esther failed by wasting the video game medium for its narrative, The Stanley Parable succeeded by making full use of video game mechanics, and then subverts them in a humourous, and yet elegant way.This game is designed to be played several times, and the real value of this game is to see what happens when you stray from the narrative that the game sets the player out to follow.I will not discuss the specifics of this game, as doing so will ruin the sense of discovery so vital to keeping the experience effective, Instead, I will tell you to go pick it up and experience it, several times. You will not regret it.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												Giving this game a thrumb up is as hard as giving it a thrumb down.The Stanley Parable is a WITTY game. Pros:+ Multiple Endings+ Good immersive deriving from interactions with the Narrator+ Impressive combination of scene and narration+ Countless Easter Eggs+Cons:- Short contents- Pseudo-intelletual plot-In the game, the game-makers show us an interesting story with their inspirational thinking through the endless loop of our protagnist, Stanley's fate. It trys to discuss the probabilities that derive from obedience and rebellion, and to achieve a high-level of interaction between players and the game. I cannot allege it is successful, but this attempt is praisable.Various endings is an attraction of the game. Among those endings, my favoriate one is the 'Crazy Ending', which will be achieved by walking down the stairs instead of up. The final narration is so good that it makes me feel I am Stanley, and being assisted by repetitive rooms, description of thinking and the style of stream-of-consciousness, it gives players an intense atomsphere and great immersive. Every ending is so distictive and interesting that can inspire players to try every choice over and over again. Under those circunstances, I think, it is as a metapher, instead of as a simple character, that should Stanley be defined.The narrator is the most important role in the game. It is he who continuously pushs the story forward and guides Stanley into different endings. He can be regarded as a highlight and also a drawback of the game. His words and tone contribute to game's style and atmosphere, but also undermine it's reality. If most of the narration can be replaced by text and make it focus on pushing the climax(just like what he does in the Crazy Ending), it would be more splendid.Except those advantages, this game is quite boring. Although it seems like players are exploring the game, but they not. All they can do is just walk along the routes that pre-designed by game-makers, and repetitive narration helps me comfirm it. Simply, throughout the game what players play is to choose 'left or right?'. It does provide some interesting things, but the gameplay and replaybility are poor. But you can regarded it as a voiced novel.Another drawback is that the game is so short that players can beat it within 10 mins. Although it contains multiple endings and the plot will be changed just result from slight changes in choices——it is still too short →_→. $15 is too much, so I strongly suggest anyone who wants to try this game keep waiting for this game apparing in bundles.How to define this game? Or, more prudently，should it be defined as a game?Without a doubt it is a good experiment. Yet, compared with novels and movies of the same type, The Stanley Parable seems still primitive.

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 26, 2014
												Prepare for spoilers. Normally I don't spoil, but it's mighty hard with this one.To enjoy The Stanley Parable, it takes a peculiar type of person. Or types of persons. There is no 'action' to speak of in this game. No guns to shoot and, debatably, not even a failure condition. (even if you CAN die...)I've been troubled in finding the best way to describe this game. People have called it a mind♥♥♥♥, something that messes with your logic. But from the moment I defied the narrator, I never felt like that. I didn't feel like I was being tossed around with. I felt like I was in a thought experiment. A thought experiment that got out of hand and resulted in other thought experiments, until it had evolved into a narrative in how I'm seemingly breaking the purpose of these by simply not cooperating.What I've concluded is that The Stanley Parable is a narrative genius. A statement on multiple facets. For example, the question can be asked how the power of the narrator compares to that of a hypothetical God? And what if the subjects in the universe the narrator and/or hypothetical god are ruling, become sentient?But that's not the only question that can surface. Your question could be "how defiant can I be and not die? What if death is part of the pathway and continuing forward will actually result in a different outcome based on the fact that I died?"Yes, that seems like a very long and convoluted question...But that's what this game does. It makes you question the reality it resides in. The non-eucledian level design (Google it) means that any progress is progress permitted to you by the narrator. But then you reach a point where even the narrator questions their own power and choices.Or you could have taken such choices that angered the narrator so much that he instead turned confrontational and made you face the fact that, even if you are walking around, you are still an automaton of a human pressing buttons.Maybe you instead drive the narrator so desperate enough that his last resort is a splendor of a room with particle effects where he seems to feel at peace and happy, with your only physical choice being to stand there for eternity, or kill yourself, stealing away the narrator's happiness.In that perspective, you could question whether you are Stanley to begin with. Maybe Stanley is a very complicated tool for you to control the narrator. Maybe you are the hypothetical God, whom's tenacity can undo or counter anything the narrator does or commands.I am far from done on describing What this game is like. The narrator could be a villain, a desperate companion, a frustrated writer... But what stands central is choice. You can only move and interact, but the choices you physically make can last so far that you wonder... not if you should do it, but what first?The Stanley Parable can be funny. Can be sad, inspiring pity within. But should you really forget yourself? Who are you anyway? Are you even real? Do you even exist? Who says you are not dreaming this and are still pressing those buttons on that keyboard?But there is one central truth to this game: It rewards semi-lineair exploration. It's not open world, but it can very much be explored and said exploration can get out of hand. And that's where the strength of the storytelling comesIf you like narration, spoken by a very skilled narrator, and like to pay attention to the story (as non traditional as this very much is) then you'll be in for a treat.But again, I can't state this enough: this is not a game for people who only wish action and effects. Such people will probably find this a boring experience, so be forewarned. If you can bring yourself to slow down your pace and allow yourself to think, you may yet enjoy it.Because I sure did. As an amateur writer, The Stanley Parable has employed many narrative tools and tricks, chastizing or rewarding you for falling for them, or not doing so at all. Carrots on a stick and red herrings, It is a thought experiment encompassing several of it's kind with a carefully laid out madness.I wish I could keep on writing about this game. But I have to stop at some point.Good job, Galactic Cafe.

												This game is great. I would say almost as brilliant as Portal. Just try it, you'll like it if you like Portal.Edit:I was pondering what to add to this review, but I can't. The story is self-explanatory enough (and I do not want to spoil it, that is half the fun), and the mechanics is just brilliant. I would and I will just say this: the game itself is amazing, but the best part is the thought behind such a concept, and will ask you some questions that you will never think of when you are playing other games.If you want another CoD / HL2 shooty-blasty-killing FPS variant, this is not the game that you want, BUT...if you want to play a thought-driven experimental with will-crafted humor like Portal, you would enjoy this game as much as I did, and remember this experience for a long time.As for the price itself, I almost got every content within the eight hours that I played, so the original price is not that good compare to other games that can let you be enjoyable for hours and hours for 15 bucks (or less). But I think the price is well worth-it if you got it on sale (I got it for 40% off and I'm satisfied for the content at the price).I would strongly-suggested that you do not read any reviews that contains spoilers, any videos that has gameplay footage on it, and even the trailers that posted on this very page, just experience it (demo or the full game) and enjoy, employee 427.

												I had high expecations for this game, but I was still suprised about how good it actually is.This is the closest you'll get to having a real choice in video games. Multiple endings and converations with several answers are merely an illusion of having a free will.Even the biggest roleplaying games feel like being on a railcar that drives you through a storyline in comparison with The Stanley Parable.The duration of a single playthrough is short, but everytime you start anew, everything can and will be different. Even choosing the same path over and over again, will be different from the first, second and even third time you did.I highly recommend playing it, to give yourself the chance to see what a truly interactive game can be -- and not just by the watered-down definition the medium uses.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
												Every once in a while, it's nice to come across a game that you weren't expecting, the kind of game that creeps up on you and then stays with you long after you've finished playing.  The Stanley Parable was originally developed as a Source engine mod back in 2010. Its creator Davey Wreden said that he set out to discover something about video games that hadn't been explored yet. More specifically, what would happen if you could disobey their rules.The game tells the story of Stanley, an average man who finds solace in his simple mundane office job. However on one particular day it appears that all his co-workers have suddenly disappeared. Guided by the narrator, Stanley must step out of the safety of his little cubical and begin his adventure to find out what exactly is going on. At first glance it might seem easy to categorise this as another artsy "walk 'em up" in the vein of something like Dear Esther or Proteus. It has a simple setting, lots of long-winded narration, not much to interact with and of course no jump or weapons, so what exactly do you do in The Stanley Parable? Well, essentially you make decisions. This is because the driving force behind the game is that of "choice". You decide HOW you play the game, and the game responds accordingly. And these decisions may appear simple, left or right? Over there? Over here? Touch that?Meanwhile you're guided by the soothing sound of 'the narrator' voiced brilliantly by British voice actor Kevan Brighting! The narrator attempts to lead you to successfully complete the game by advising you which path to take as well as narrating the inner monologue of the troubled protagonist Stanley. And it's through this narration that the game achieves a level of hysterical self awareness and brilliant charm very similar to the Portal series. This dynamic narration will react to the decisions you make, often breaking the fourth wall to talk to you directly. And should you decide not to listen to these directions and "disobey" the resulting dialogue and consequences can easily spiral out of control into the strange and surreal. But to say anymore would no doubt ruin your experience of The Stanley Parable as no two play throughs are really the same. And multiple play throughs are inevitable in a game that encourages you to poke and prod at its structure, almost everyone I know who've played this walked away from this game with a different story to tell. Depending on how your experience plays out, at some stage or another you will no doubt be forced to return to Stanley's office to once again set out to look for your co-workers, and it's here that you might decide to stop playing the game and that's totally fine, but in my experience, once you've been presented with so many variables, it's very hard to resist that urge to go back and try out every possible deviation, especially when they can alter the game so radically beyond your expectations. And this kind of thinking is just so refreshing, I found myself laughing with confusion and disbelief because every time I pushed the game, it would push back. I guess the only disappointing moment was when I came to the stark realisation that the game couldn't possibly live up to the illusion of infinite choice. However this was more bitter sweet, as I soon came to the realisation that any game that gave me this feeling of absolute freedom, if only for the briefest moment in time, was truly remarkable.The Stanley Parable might not be for everyone, but in my opinion it should be played by everyone. It's a hilarious experiment in psychology and non-linear game design that will probably teach you more about yourself as a gamer than you might want to know.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
												Are you an experienced gamer?  Have you played enough games that you instinctively recognize the tropes and common things that all games do, but can't quite put a finger on them?  Would you like a game that points them all out, and makes it amusing at the same time?  Good.  The Stanley Parable does that.Well, I mean, that's where it starts.  First it puts its finger right on those tropes, pointing them out, having a chuckle.  Then the whole hand.  Then it shoves its hand through the tropes and the wall behind them, shattering a hole into a Escher-like dimension of allegory and humor spiraling endlessly around a story that deliberately falls afoul of the same tropes it works so hard to identify and undermine.Then the game restarts, or maybe it doesn't restart.  Maybe you restarted it, but did you restart it because you wanted to, or because the game wanted you to?  And is this really a game anymore?To perhaps make that rambling a bit more clear, The Stanley Parable is a game about a man, which is really allegory about games, which in turn is a metaphor about life and choice and free will and about a billion other things.  There are so many layers to the story you could get lost in it all, but the beauty is that you don't have to.  You can be philisophical about what it all means, or you can simply laugh hysterically at the spot on narration describing, bemoaning, and sometimes belittling you, the story, and who knows what else.In short, The Stanley Parable is a beautiful mix of humor, philosophy, allegory, and self-aware commentary on video games, requiring almost no skill to understand and enjoy.  It is a masterpiece that blurs the line between game, story, commentary, and art.

Posted: December 5, 2013
												The Stanley Parable is actually a pretty hard game to recommend. The first time you'll play it you'll probably be like "Wtf?" but the more you play it and the more different you play it the more it starts to make sense, atleast it did for me. I actually have no idea how to describe without spoiling it, I can only say that each of your own choices will lead to a different outcome. I honestly don't think that The Stanley Parable could be described as a game that belongs to a certain genre, it's pretty weird but yet, mindblowing genious. Possible one of the greatest achievements in videogaming narrative and storytelling and a very successfull one too. Be warned, there are different endings to the game and I don't even know if I got them all and no I didn't even bothering looking up and no I don't care if I got them all because the way I see it I played through this game with no knowledge of it whatsoever and that resulted in an amazing experience, one which everyone should try.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												This game is definetly worth playing. However, it is important to understand that it's even less gaming-game than Telltale's or Quantic Dream projects. This is a glorious game-designing experience which is built around the narrator. Literally, just like in the famous 'Bastion', you've got a narrator that describes your every step, every idea you got in your head. And that's how it goes 'till the moment you face a small divarication. Two doors, and the voice above you, the voice that you've been listening as if it was your own, tells you to pick the left one. And you may follow this order, and end the game sooner or later. You'll get your ending, and will be happy with it, I suppose. But what would have happened if you had chosen the diffirent path? That's when the game actually begins.This is not a drama movie and not a horror fiction. Actually, it is pretty funny and will make you a little bit happier, if you'd like. This is not even a 'story', just a small sandbox, which you can use to play with your narrator. Or... Maybe it is you that is being played? It's not gonna take a long time to complete this game, but after that you'll remember Stanley for a long, long time.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2016
The Stanley Parable				* 8/10This is not just a common game and it's quite unique in its approach to the player.Technically this is just a walking simulator, but it has no importance at all, because gameplay has not much to do with the game as it could have been an isometric point'n'click, a sidescrolling arcade or whatever you want. The core of the game is the way it relates and plays with the player.As the title suggests this is a story about Stanley, an employee living a monotone life and working in an office when all of a sudden he realizes the entire floor is empty. And here the player begins the game. The real core of the gme though is the Narrator's voice, the way he describes your actions and guides you. There's a canon ending where you hear Stanley's story where he finally realizes he's free and all, but that lame and simple specious ending has nothing to do with the game itself, in my opinion. In fact you simply have to blindly follow the narrator's directions to finish it in 15 mins or so. The real point of the game is in the huge amount of variations derived by all the choices you're being presented, the Narrator's reactions breaking the 4th wall both with Stanley and the player itself more than you'd expect and the way the game evolves in multiple directions and restart in different variations, resulting more in a comedy than a parable.The engine is the good old trusty Source Engine, and the office and other ambiences have been well built with a simple but effective level of detail.Unfortunately there's not much music in game but it's kind of right this way, as it would break the atmosphere of the game.+++PROs+++ NARRATOR. The real core of the game is not to beat the game, nor Stanley himself or his parable, but it's the narrator. It's all about the choices you make and his reactions that can drive the story to an incredible number of variations, from tragedy, to comedy at the limit of ridiculous with the narrator breaking the 4th wall not only with Stanley but with the player as well.---CONs--- UNCOMMON. The unusual structure of the game might not look appealing to the most conventional players, as they could finish the game with the canon ending in 10-15 minutes not realizing that the purpose of the game lies in testing the limits of all the choices and variables and seeing the game evolve and degenerate as the narrator hilariously comments your actions and choices... Even if you're doing nothing at all! As a "traditional" gamer myself I've been lucky enough because I chose to never listen the Narrator since the very beginning (I didn't trust him XD) to finish with a sad and nonsense ending that slowly brought me back at the beginning. Since then I started trying various alternatives.I played this game on this machine:Laptop Lenovo Z50Intel Core i5-4210U8Gb RAM DDR3GeForce 840MIntel HD Graphics 4400Windows 10 Home x64And on this machine:Intel Core i7-497016Gb RAM DDR3GeForce GTX 660Windows 10 Professional x64

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												The Stanley Parable is very in love with itself.As what I can only describe as an abstract rumination on contemporary game design, Galactic Café’s The Stanley Parable is, from its opening moments, confident to the point of near irreverence. I suppose it’s understandable to a degree, as The Stanley Parable is undeniably witty and unconventional, with a quirky charm and dry self-awareness. It is so overwhelmingly eccentric that it can begin to feel as if not playing along with it and laughing at every joke is an act of disrespect, such is the perception The Stanley Parable cultivates within moments of leaving the main menu to venture forth into a cornucopia of contextually appropriate satire and bizarre dark humor.The Stanley Parable gives off such a sense of self-prescribed brilliance that I feel both dumbfounded and maybe even a little angry at just how much I dislike it. I get the joke and admire its delivery, but when approached from any angle but the one the game so strongly attempts to cultivate, The Stanley Parable feels like little more than a few intelligent observations on modern game design strung along by a series of amusing, yet immensely inconsistent and inscrutable scenes with no conclusions to be found.I understand that the lack of closure is part of the point. I can find a certain poetic appreciation for the circular design of the game, and as a lesson in abstract game design The Stanley Parable certainly gets marks for trying. But then it tries some more, and eventually (which is to say sometime within the first 20 minutes of play) I became rather weary of hearing the same joke play out as I raged a supposedly hilarious war with the narrator over increasingly innocuous choices.There is such an abundance of creativity to be admired within The Stanley Parable, one would think that even in worst case scenarios everyone will be able to find something to like buried in its labyrinth of compounding decisions. But by design each disconnected moment is compiled with the next, creating a sequence of random and oddly directed scenes for which the primary goal is to disorient the player as they continue bumbling through a game with no rules and a rather antagonistic sense of progression.The Stanley Parable without a doubt knows what it’s doing. The script is tight, the pacing smooth, and the overall concept worthy of praise. And yet I found myself despising every moment I spent with the game. The more I tried to peel back its layers to find the game I had seen praised to the ends of the earth and back, the more I was confronted with the same shallow and narcissistic experience that only became more meandering and unfulfilling the longer I stuck with it. I suppose it was fitting that I eventually arrived in a museum dedicated to the game itself; an internal monument to a project which clearly recognizes its own genius even as I struggle to understand the appeal.You can read more of my writing on Kritiqal[kritiqal.com].

content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
												I really enjoyed 'The Stanley Parable', I enjoyed it the same way some obessive about movies enjoys an movie critique and other examples that I can't honestly think of right now.Does the fact that I enjoyed this game, and I mean I enjoyed it a lot actually makes this game a good game though? ( I hope no one gets man, since the whole point of the game is to get people to think and ask questions). As a whole, I don't honestly think so. As a game I think 'The Stanley Parable' is pretty mediocre in terms of its mechanics and aesthetics. Its narrator and script are top notch though and really carry the game ensuring that its tone and mood are always spot on. As a whole, I think people should play this game, its the equivilent to visiting an art museam in my opinion, just a bit more engaging.A more robust review of the game can be found on my blog over here: http://mouseandcontroller.blogspot.com/2014/03/the-stanley-parable.html.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												While Antichamber uses philosophical wisecracking as mere specific hints for solving puzzles and Dear Esther doesn't really deserve to be called an interactive story, playing The Stanley Parable is like going on a spiritual journey. There's a massive feedback effect, making you reflect about your own life. The way it messes with your head I could compare to some of the experiences I had on ayahuasca... how it first tries to confuse you so that you begin to get your narrow rational mind out of the way and open yourself to the big questions. The fact that this 'game' (it's definitely a game if you consider life one, too) has no real end further supports that training character, not unlike the Dao De Jing that you can keep reading again and again and gain new insights every time. While a desire for 'completing' it might eventually get the best of you and make you consult guides, you're definitely not meant to know all there is in this game. It is part of the experience to not have the full view on everything.Big themes in The Stanley Parable are the idea of free will and personal responsibility for your decisions, as well as the purpose of life, the challenges we face, destiny and the nature of reality. ... Yeap, this is a vast little game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 10, 2014
												WHAT THE STANLEY PARABLE IS - NO SPOILERSTL;DR: Play the demo avaliable on Steam to quickly see exactly "what the game is about".The Stanley Parable is a game about making choices that is simple in terms of mechanics (WASD/arrow keys to move, E to interact with objects, mouse to look around, that's it)  but it is very unconventional in other aspects such as plot development or character presentation.You play in first person view as an unsettlingly ordinary office worker named Stanley, in a story that begins with him realizing that all his coworkers have suddenly vanished. What really enriches the story is the omnipresent, amusing narrator (voiced by Kevan Brighting) who eventually contributes to the story much more than simply narrating it.This story branches out to multiple, very different endings depending on what the player chooses to do. The brilliance of the game is how these choices change much more than just the plot, because the game does not proceed with conventional video game logic, sometimes even criticizing it. For example, the narrator's personality changes according to how you play and sometimes he breaks the fourth wall to comment on your decisions as the player. The achievement system and how "glitches" are handled are other examples of this. The game is also sprinkled with secrets and easter eggs for the more curious players to search for. I find The Stanley Parable to be a thought-provoking and insightful on matters like the power of choices, the illusion of free choice, and what a video game really is or could be. Despite its brilliance The Stanley Parable is a short experience, although it is still likely to stick around in your mind for a long time, even after you found all of the endings.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												I will start by saying that this review contains mild spoilers, so if you haven't played the game yet, I highly suggest that you take caution before reading this review.I was not familiar with the original Half-Life 2 mod that The Stanley Parable started out with. Heck, I only heard about this game through word of mouth. The Stanley Parable is what happens when you take an interesting concept that you probably wouldn't dare put into a videogame, and actually make it work. The story (if you can call it that) is of a man named Stanley who works at a boring job in an office building, pushing buttons that his boss tells him to push via his monitor. One day, he notices that his boss hasn't given him a single command the entire day, and appears to have gone missing, along with his co-workers.That's where the gimmick of the game takes place. While there is a narrative telling you what to do throughout the game, you have a choice to follow it or stray from it. Depending on what decisions you make throughout the game, there are a total of 14 different endings in this game. This can range from ]turning off the power in a mind-control facility that has been controlling all of the thoughts and feelings of the workers in the building, including Stanley, to entering a homage of a small string of existing videogames. The thing I like about this game is that there isn't a morality meter. The choices you make aren't necessarily based on thoughts, but actions. Not only that, but some of the endings are based off of bugs, glitches and whatnot that were in the original mod (Try closing the door on yourself as you start the game.)The Stanley Parable is almost entirely psychological. During the time that it was still just a mod, the creator, Wreden,  thought up the game considering how most games on the market "confine the user to its rules." The dialogue in the game is very thought-provoking at times, and I've even seen some players and journalists state that it made them think about their own lives. The thought that a simple game like this can have so much influential power on someone like that is remarkable, and I applaud Galactic Cafe for this.The presentation is definetly not anything to turn your head at either. The visuals are vastly different in this game than anything you would see in Half-Life 2 (Go figure). When the developers said they were going to make an HD remake of this game, they weren't screwing around. No hallway nor room looks the same (unless designed intentionally), and everything looks crisp and clear. The music is a nice touch as well, perfectly fitting the locale and scenario that takes place. The voice acting is also a department I have to give major props to. Kevan Brighting does a fantastic job as the voice of the narrator, depicting emotions of happiness, despair, confusion, anger, worry, really the list goes on. He even goes through an evil persona during one of the endings.As I stated before, 14 endings is a lot for a game, but it is still quite a short game. Is there anything else that might convince you to take a second glance at the fifteen dollar price tag? Perhaps. The Stanley Parable may be a short game at its core, but there are a ton of secrets to be found within the different branching pathways. Extended dialogue, little visual easter eggs, and areas of the map you probably didn't even know existed until you did a little exploration. The developers really thought of everything when making this game. (Try typing sv_cheats 1 in the console. I dare you.)If you're one of those people who enjoys a non-linear experience in your videogames, as well as comedic and witty dialogue, then I highly reccomend The Stanley Parable for you. However, if you're still not sure about the fifteen dolar price tag, I advise trying out the demo first. It's actually a unique experience from the official game, and you might like what you see.

Posted: August 16, 2015
												The Stanley Parable is one of those games that you really have to like in order to play properly. Otherwise, it's going to feel like a complete waste of time, totally pointless, maybe even offensively boring. The Stanley Parable is a metaphysical experience that begins right after the studio logo loading screen. The main menu itself is already the first step into a hilarious spiral of deconstructive video game analysis.I really can't say much about the game itself without spoiling anything, and you really REALLY need to play this game without any prior knowledge of what it's about.All you need to know is: I recommend this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 20, 2014
												The very first thing that should be mentioned about the Stanley Parable is that it is short. Very short. This is not to say the game is not worth getting, quite the contrary. However, waiting for a good sale is probably the most prudent course of action given the length of the game.In a way the Stanley Parable is like a Choose Your Own Adventure book. While you play as Stanley, the narrator will tell the story of Stanley and which actions the narrator wishes you to follow. However, there are multiple points where you can choose to follow the narrator or not. When choosing to follow the narrator, it is possible to complete the game in a little over four minutes, but the fun is in exploring all of the various paths and seeing the various endings to the game. The narration is done wonderfully, and as the narrator becomes frustrated with your choices, the game can become rather comical.  The game is an exporation in story telling, and while simple, it is very well done.

												Let’s start this game off by saying as an achievement ♥♥♥♥♥ getting the 430 achievement of this game had me laughing to the point where I hurt.The Stanley Parable is a great satirical look at our modern society and gaming culture. If you just follow what you’re told you miss out on so much of this game and every moment of it is great. Though it is pretty short if you follow the narrator seeking out the other possibilities makes this game endlessly entertaining. One of the best things about this game is how much you can miss if you take it at face value. It is almost necessary to do some of the achievements as they are the developer trolling players about the things they do to earn achievements in games.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2014
The Stanley Parable is impossible to truly describe. At its most tame, it's an incredible psychological experience that will stay with you for the rest of your life. It has an outstanding blend of humor and seriousness, wrapped in the type of weirdness you can only find in games like EarthBound or Katamari Damacy. It pokes a lot of fun at various video game tropes, sometimes subtly, sometimes flamboyantly. It makes the player think about their life and the validity and consequences of choice and free will. And it does all this while maintaining a simple but intelligent gameplay experience. So the real question is not what The Stanley Parable has to offer, but rather what you are willing to obtain from it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												The Stanley Parable is easily my favorite game of 2013. The humor is top-notch (whether it's light-hearted like the Adventure Line or one of the many fantastic times it gets dark) and the Narrator is a fantastic and very well-acted character -- the staircase ending is legitimately among the most affecting scenes I've encountered in a videogame. I can't recommend picking this up more.If you haven't yet, make sure to pick up the demo too - not only is it free but it also has absolutely no content from the full game in it, instead attempting (quite successfully) to show off the humor and style you'll encounter. It's very much worth trying out.

												I thought I had cleared The Stanley Parable after a mere 2 hours of play. Surely, I thought, I had cleared it after 5 hours? After 7 hours I have taken each possible route and explored the corners of this game to the best of my ability and realize that I probably have still not cleared it.To some this would mean the game is worth its 12€ price tag and to some it would be exactly why it isn't worth it at all. To some it would not even be considered a game. I'm not too sure on that point myself but I can say that it is an experience. Such is the paradox that is The Stanley Parable, It really is whatever you make of it. I think I have squeezed its value out of it but some may never feel they got their moneys worth. Is it worth the price? I couldn't say. Is it a good game? I don't really know. Is it even a game? Not sure.

												A flawlessly executed analysis of gaming conventions, spoken and unspoken. Like its contemporary fellow experience-a-thons Gone Home and Dear Esther, it's a bold innovation in storytelling. number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												I have no words to describe this game. So i will try the best i can."The Stanley Parable" is a game that isn't a game, it isn't something you "play", neither is something with an objective. It's a narrative that, at first, seems really linear, but, when you start to explore, there will be a mass amount of possibilities.Different from most games, you don't have a prize at the end, there's no reward or resolution whatsoever, the only thing that you get is a different ending each time that you play it in a different way. Witch is pretty good! Because i can, by my actions, see the resolution to MY story.Witch gets me to the first topic: The Story.The story is simples: You are Stanley, a normal worker that only press buttons everyday. And this it. Many times in the game, it seems that you have a wife to take care of and because of she, you can't get out of your prison, that is your work. But when you receive no more orders, you get out of your office and see that everyone that worked with you was gone, without any trace of what happened whatsoever. That's where YOUR story begins. The game does an awesome job making you and Stanley the same person. This is your story and you will decide what to do with it. You can follow the voice of The Narrator (witch can be a protagonist or an antagonist, depending on your actions) or make your own way. There's a lot of endings ("Normal" ending, The Nuclear Explosion Ending, The Crazy Stanley Ending, The Adventure Line Ending, The Escape Ending, The "You Actually Made A Choise" Ending, The Death Of Stanley Ending, The Space Ending, The Serious Ending, The Story Of Stanley And His Wife Ending, The "But Stanley Couldn't Force Himself" Ending, The "I'm Sick Of This Gag" Ending, The "I'm Not Sick Of This Gag" Ending, The Stanley Heaven Ending (this one is quite awesome, buttons everywhere :D), The WhiteBoard Ending and The "Since You Don't Like This Game, Let's Try Another One" (This one has a total of three posibilities: The one where the narrator takes you directly to the "baby game", the one that, before he takes you to his game, he takes you to Minecraft and Portal and the one that, while you are in Portal, you can walk to the elevator, fall on it and actually step in the original "The Stanley Parable" mod game). I don't know if i forgot some, but for me, it's a total of 18 endings (counting the multiple possibilities of the "Don't like this game" ending). I also don't know if all of then are right, i don't remember they correctly, but i'm certain that THEY ARE in this game.The sound is actually...Well, there must be like 3 musics on the game. That's because the most important is The Narrator's voice. It remembers A LOT GLaDOS from Portal. Not just because it's actually pretty well done, but because it varies so much, sometimes he is just mocking with you, others, he just trying to help you. And this goes on and on...You never know when the narrator is your friend or your enemy, only your actions will change how he is with you and how you will like him or not.Gameplay is quite simple. You walk and interact. Most doors don't open, but there a quite few Easter Eggs through the scenarios that will only activate when you complety a certain action. Some achievements requires this. (Including one that's pretty obvious).Overall, great "game". Because, most people consider this a thing that it's different from a game. It's fun, it tricks with your mind, it has a lot of content hidden and, when you're done with, you still don't know how to describe this. That's the magic of this "game". It shows not only how videogames should be, but how with simply follow the orders that is given to us in gaming, instead of doing what we want. The freedom, paradox and immersion of this game is what it made it so special and so acclaimed by both the users and the critic. This is a 10/10 without doubt, a piece of art and maybe one of the best games i have ever played.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 8, 2016
												The Stanley Parable is a very interesting. It tells some fantastic jokes, makes some self-indulgent commentary, but then it proceeds to get stranger and more intimate and less pointed and more interesting the more you poke at it. It isn't making fun of games for the sake of some self-appointed enlightened savior of gaming and it doesn't seem to be strange for the sake of strangeness.What makes Stanley Parable feel so fresh isn't the humor or the satire or the criticsm that's baked into it--those are enjyoable, but they weren't what impressed me. What makes it feel fresh is how intimately it converses with the player. I'm reminded very much of a game called Save the Date--though that was a smaller and simpler affair. Both games start with meta commentary and then submerge from there, talking carefully with you about how the narrator, creator or other characters think, feel and the ramifications of that for your behavior and your experience of the product. The secret of both of these games which drape themselves in the trappings of meta-narrative is that they do actually contain characters who you will learn about, be asked to empathize with, be asked to listen to, and be asked, after it all, to act on your conclusions should you have reached any.They are games that start with the nature of games, then the nature of reality, and then quietly, timidly, reveal that at their heart they are about the same intimacies and relationships as most intersting or moving stories. For all of the delightful jokes, strangeness, non-linearity and surreality of The Stanley Parable my most clear feeling when I stopped playing was one of loss; I had run out of ways to communicate with this person with whom I formed a relationship. I had run out of things to say and ways to prove I was listening.I was alone.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2013
												The Stanley Parable will end; the Stanley Parable will never end. The Narrator will stop talking; the Narrator will never stop talkingMore Stanley, less StanleyFollowing the logic so far? If you are, you must be on some sort of medication.... and yes, this is the kind of logic that the Stanley Parable incorporates in it. The Stanley Parable is one of those games that make you go: “What the hell just happened?” Just like that time you somehow break the time continuum just by walking into a broom closet. The Stanley Parable is quite basic if you look at it from the outside, but if you dig deeper, then you’ll find some peculiar things. Like when you somehow get into a game that you have to save a baby from a fire by repeatedly pressing the same button that says "8". The whole game revolves mostly around the Narrator, who narrates/insults you in the game. (You Sherlock Holmes, you!) The Stanley Parable has what most games lack: choice: you can either follow the Narrator, or you can go against him to start a whole web of interesting events. When you do make these choices you get a great amount of odd happenings. Sometimes the most random things will happen that will make you fall out of your chair laughing, or things that will completely blow your mind and make you re-think life. Occasionally, you have to sit there for a moment just trying to ponder: “Did that just happen right now?”. Trust me; you’re going to get a lot of these moments from this game. The Stanley Parable is like that one guy who stands out of the group. It's just so... different. What makes the Stanley Parable so different from other games is that it takes you on a journey that will make you re-think the reality of the world. Overall: the Stanley Parable is an oddity of a game. The things you least expect may happen. So just watch out. The Stanley Parable ranges from being taunted by the Narrator all the way to getting smashed by piston platforms by random button pushing; the Stanley Parable is just a whole world of choices. It just matters on what choice YOU make. Just make sure you don’t set off a nuke on accident.Personal Gaming Score:9/10I recommend this game for those who want an interesting game to play, but not to those who want action, multiplayer games, or those who just don’t really want to “think”. Can your mind handle this game? If you think you can, or cannot but decide to get the game anyway, remember this little thing I learned:THE END IS NEVER THE END IS NEVER THE END IS NEVER THE END IS NEVER THE END IS NEVER THE END IS NEVER THE END…

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 18, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is, without any doubt, one of the best headaches I've ever had. Even though it's more of a self-telling short story than a video game, you'll have yourself shaking your head and chuckling every time you walk through it... because your walkthrough will change with the smallest decision. The Pros:· Great and entertaining narration will follow every step you take...· ... and every step you take feels surprisingly drastic, as something as little as going left or right will determine the way the story is told. · Every decision you make will spin its own web, making it a joy to replay as it will rarely be the same.· Asides from the light and humoristic narration, the game actually manages to adress some things we rarely think about, what gives you a unique sense of vulnerability even though not a single bullet will be shot or axe swung. You will have complete freedom, yet you're trapped from the very beginning.  The Cons:· Even though there are many different ways you can go, the options aren't limitless. There is no real reason to play through the game the exact same way multiple times.· Definately not for everyone. It's pure exploration that minimalises gameplay to simple environmental interactions with buttons and doors.The Looks:· The Stanley Parable runs on the Source Engine, and that shows... in a good way. The lighting and textures are phenomenal and soak you into the game's unique atmosphere that complements the entire story you get to tell. Final Verdict:Although it won't be for everyone, The Stanley Parable manages to suck you into its complexely simple story that is a joy to discover and rediscover differently the next time you play it. 8/10.

content:
Posted: February 17
												The Stanley Parable is a bag of candy that seems almost endless. Seriously, every 30 seconds, "Oh! Piece of candy". Whether the "candy" is a brilliant easter egg, a well-constructed story element or whatever, it's great. Every path you take has a durastic affect on the outcome, each has it's own funny take on the path you've chosen. You have the choice to obey or disobey the narrator, who takes notice of you disobey him. But as I said at the beginning, this game is a bag of candy that seems almost endless. I got all the endings in 2 and  a half hours, and while it was a grand time, it was over quickly. The bag of candy had ran out. I knew every thing that was going to happen, nothing to suprise me after all the endings were found. Sure, going back to the endings would still be funny, but they wouldn't have the same puch they did on your first playthrough of them. You feel let down because this wonderful bag of candy which had the "Rich neighborhood on Halloween candy" now have "From the depths of grandma's purse which makes you say,"How long has that been in there?"candy". While I recommend you get this game, beware; You'll get what you wanted, but it won't last forever.

YouTube™ Video: MOB Review: The Stanley Parable 

			Views: 85		

			The Stanley Parable a narrative lead story Available here: Steam: http://store.steampowered.com/app/221910/ HomePage: http://www.stanleyparable.com/ Join us at Twitter or Facebook if that is your...		

	A parable is defined as a succinct story which illustrates one or more instructive lessons or principles using analogy. The Stanley Parable is a narration based game told from a first person perspective .  Through the eyesof the main character, Stanley, you are taken on many bizarre, twistingadventures  narrated by sarcastic, hilarious inner dialogue that explore themeaning of life, and ferns though parables.	The gameplay is fairly basic.  As you progress through the levels, it offers choices that affect your current and future playthroughs. The level design is layer upon layer of rooms that seem to twist in on themselves to confuse your sense of direction and add to the story.  The story never trulyends, until the player decides it does. 	There is not a lot of depth in the game, but there is a lot of choice.  The story plus the narrations is entertaining, amusing, and charming, and wortha few hours of play through.  It plays on our natural curiosity, making us wonder what there is yet to discover.  The end is not the endThis is a summary of what I talk about in the video, I am a YT'er not a BloggerThanks for your viewership and support for more videos check click here.http://www.youtube.com/user/SocioPyscho

												I wanted to love this game, I really did. For the first hour, it seemed great!  In a couple of endings, like the Confusion Ending, each time the game was reset it would effect the next run. However, during other runs, this is not the case.  So after about 2 hours, it just got boring and repititive. I had completed practically every ending, and I see no reason to return to it. It was fun while it lasted, but not very replayable.I bought it for $3 when it was 80% off, so for that much it was probably worth it. But I couldn't imagine paying $15 for 2-3 hours of gameplay. If its on sale, I would recommend getting it. You will enjoy it for a few hours straight. But after, it will get boring and you'll probably have no reason to keep playing it.

number of helpful: 185 of 356 people (52%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I am slightly conflicted about giving a negative review for this game. The game seems witty enough. There is a narrator and he does a wonderful job.However, there's not much to really do apart from walk around and listen to the narrator. The amount of content is severely lacking - you could 'finish' the game within 5 minutes, although it is meant to be played through more than once. The replayability, which is supposed to be one of the game's strong suits, eventually becomes a weakness. Once you've seen an ending, you may not want to bother seeing it again.The Stanley Parable reminded me of a 'Choose Your Own Adventure' book, but choice alone does not lend itself very well to gaming. Interaction is what makes gaming different and fun, and the game has little interaction further than choosing which door to enter.I don't think The Stanley Parable lives up to all the praise that is heaped on it (mainly by critics). If you're going to get it, wait until it is heavily discounted. Or get Antichamber instead.

content:
Posted: October 21, 2013
												The Stanley Parable is a very small game world that is, narratively, expansive. It is one of the many recent games that is more of an experience than a game. It is very short (all experriences can be had within a couple of hours), so the price-sensitive may wish to wait for a significant sale. Otherwise, you are in for a great ride that will have you saying "whoa, no way!" several times throughout. I picked this up, having been waiting for what seemed like eons for it to come out, without knowing what to expect. I left it with a huge smile on my face and hoping that there will be a more expansive experience based on this idea in the future. It deserves more depth and room to grow.Besides, where else will you find a game with an achivement to "play for the entire duration of a Tuesday" and "don't play this game for five years"?

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 12, 2014
												I'm not sure I should be writing this review yet, because I'm not sure I've reached every ending yet. I think I've broken double digits? Whatever, not running a game into the ground hasn't stopped me before, so here it is!Buy it. Boom. Done. You need this game in your life. Because it's not just a game, but a story. And not a story like most first person shooters are stories, but it's a story that's 100% about player choice. Some of these choices are hilarious (the Confusion Ending, the Whiteboard Ending) while other result in your death (the Escape Ending, the Downstairs Ending); many of them find a way to re-route you to the beginning of the game, with minor cosmetic changes that leave you uncertain as to whether or not you're truly restarting.The game's primary draw has to be the narration. The VO is soothing, witty, full of emotion; it's also surprisingly complete, with many dialogues going on much longer than one would expect. The game is all about the joy of discovery, and the narration encapsulates this perfectly, as you can't wait to hear what he says next.Because of the nature of The Stanley Parable, it does get repetitive after a while. This is why it's best to set aside a full day (preferably a Tuesday) to play through everything at once, so the game can continuously update itself for you. It'll be a good day, I promise.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 21, 2013
												At first, I was going to write a full-length (yes, even longer than this) and in-depth review about this game. Then I realised that it would be way too hard and complex to do, because this game isn't really a game. Totalbiscuit however did an amazing job trying to explain the very nature of this... game (see link below).The Stanley Parable is more of an interactive story than a game. Or, interactive stories, to be exact. The Stanley Parable consists of somewhat short stories (~20 minutes each), and the choices you make during gameplay affects the ending(s) you get. Because that is mostly what this game is all about; making choices. And yet, the choices you make, don't have that much of an impact, because it's all already planned out. Kevan Brightning does a truly amazing job voicing The Narrator, person, who tells you how story should continue and what you should do. I cannot emphasize enough how brilliant his voice acting is in this game; his voice and the way he plays out his lines are perfect. His voice acting is one of the most considerable factors why this game is so good.The job of this very unique masterpiece is to question everything. To question decisions, life, nature/linearity/plot of other games and the whole existence (of itself and others). Because that is what this game is also about; it is supposed to wake up some thoughts in you. To wake you up to think. To wake you up to things around you and how you're living. To wake you up to the fact, how much your choices actually have an impact on anything at all. To wake up any thought in you.I strongly, I repeat, STRONGLY recommend you to play at least the demo version of this game. It will give you at least some sort of an idea of this game. You can find the link below, but remember that the real version of this game is even better.So, as overall, this "game" is brilliant and it is also very unique, truly one of a kind. It is worth of the experience, and it is worth of the thoughts it should wake up in you. You should try this "game" yourself to understand the very nature of it. Because The Stanley Parable is something you can't explain verbally.RATING: 90/100-AsplodeLink to the Totalbiscuit's video:

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
												Stanley Parable originally was a mod for original Half-Life 2, a story about a man Stanley who works in an office, his job is simple, press buttons, one day though his usual day gets interrupted, everyone goes missing...Stanley decides to explore.......And..that's all what I can really tell you..I don't want to go deeper into the game, I would spoil everything and by that I'd ruin everything.----------------------Stanley Parable is a unique experience which cannot be seen in any other game. It manages to give us a message and thoughts to think about related to games while not taking itself seriously. I was smiling throughout the entire game while still thinking about the game and the message it's trying to get across.  The best way to experience Stanley Parable is simply not reading about it, going into it blindly. That can be a big risk for many people. That's why there is an excellent demo which shows us what you could except while not showing anything from the actual game. Narration from Kevan Brighting is perfect, if it was any different narrator the experience simply wouldn't be the same.It's hard to write about Stanley Parable, it truly is. I don't want to spoil anything. If you're still not sure try out the demo mentioned before.

Nearly unexplainable!Although the game is so great, it's hard to describe, because it's great in its own way and maybe opening a new genre of video games. You just have to play it to feel its special atmosphere and the "storyline" that is complex, confusing, thought-provoking and awesome at once.Just try it, I can only recommend it.For those who want to know of it nevertheless: It's a game comparable with a tree. You follow a story, told by a narrator, but have choices at so many points, so that there's a big range of brach lines, which lead to so many endings. The unique thing is that the narrator tells you to do it one way, but you can do it differently and get dialogues about that too. During playing The Stanley Parable you identify the narrator's character more and more and often it's very funny.I hope you can imagine more now, I tried to spoiler as little as possible, have fun with the game. :)

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
The Definitive Review of The Stanley ParableSo, I was browsing through the Stanley Parable community page, and I inevitably ended up coming across a number of reviews. To be honest, I was actually surprised at how many negative reviews it got, and not just a bit disturbed at how many people found those reviews “helpful.” After reading several of those reviews, I came to the conclusion that many gamers do not really understand The Stanley Parable or how to go about playing it. The first and most important thing I feel like I should address comes from the several reviews I read which stated how they “beat the game” in such a short amount of time, and how that made it not worth the money. The thing is, The Stanley Parable is not by any means a normal game. In fact, as many people have pointed out all over the place in a somewhat fanboyish fashion, it is not even really a “game” at all, in the familiar sense of the word. It is, in fact, exactly what it says it is: a parable. For those who don't really know what that is (don't be ashamed: I had to look it up, too), here's the definition, courtesy of the late Ms. Merriam-Webster: par·a·blenoun \ˈpa-rə-bəl\a short story that teaches a moral or spiritual lessonThe point is, you can't “beat” The Stanley Parable any more than you could beat a movie or a book. You can finish it, true. Once you've found every ending and heard every bit of dialogue, you can safely say that you've finished it; but there's no award at the end, no “Story Progress: 100%,” no achievement for finding all of the endings, nothing at all to say that you've “beaten” it. And besides, “beating” something implies that there was a challenge in the first place. The Stanley Parable isn't about any challenge; it's about exploration and discovery, along with some intriguing and entertaining psychological wizardry. Now I've talked about the “beat the game” part, I want to discuss the “length” of the game a bit. Basically, The Stanley Parable is short for a reason. Each ending probably takes no more than half an hour to reach, often less. If all the endings took even just one hour, let alone the multiple hours most modern game storylines last, nobody would have the patience or curiosity to start over and find out what happens if you do it a different way. In the end, The Stanley Parable may just not be for you. If you enjoy linear plot lines without pesky deviations and multiple endings, don't get it. If you don't have the patience to search for every possibly dialogue trigger, don't bother. If you get frustrated when you have to start something over, try something else. It's as simple as that. Think and research before you buy. If you wasted your money on The Stanley Parable, it's not because it failed to live up to your expectations, but because you did not know what to expect. Finally, here is my verdict on The Stanley Parable. An enthusiastic thumbs-up, ★★★★★, at least 94/100, whatever you want to call it; it is well-made, cleverly designed, and ingeniously implemented; the dialogue is involving, emotional, and filled with dry, quick-witted humor. In many ways it is very reminiscent of Portal – it was made in Source, after all. I absolutely love it, and I highly recommend it. Anyways, this was more or less a product of my boredom. I hope it was nevertheless helpful to some people. I did try to stay objective, except during that last paragraph, and I hope I succeeded in that. Enjoy your day, and enjoy The Stanley Parable. I know I do.

												Very interesting game. Basically, there is not really any goal in this  game (apart from finding all the endings), speaking of which, that is what this game is based upon. Endings. How many endings can you find? I liked the concept, it's very interesting and the devs had some nice ideas for the many different paths you can take. This game certainly is not for everyone as some will be disapponited by it. If you want to get this game and were say expecting a... "game" I guess? Then don't get it? It's an interesting concept but not for everybody. You decide, I enjoyed it however.

Similar to another 'experience' on steam called 'The Path', you get a clear sense of direction on what you're meant to do, and only when deciding you want to be a punk♥♥♥♥♥nay-sayer do you really find out what's what.TLDR;its a game where you can't lose :D

content:
Posted: March 16
												The Stanley Parable is a short, open-ended indie game set in a mysteriously empty office building. You, Stanley, are guided through the building by a mysterious voice who claims to want to help you escape. Although this unseen narrator tells you where to go, you're under no obligation to listen to him, and choosing to take a different route will often result in hilarious responses. There are a number of different endings, all of which are interesting in their own way. While the game does get somewhat dull after a few playthroughs, the narration is fantastic and the experience overall enjoyable. $15 is perhaps a bit much to ask for this game, but I would recommend it if you can get it on sale.

content:
Posted: October 18, 2013
												James stared at the blank text entry quadrangle trying to piece together his thoughts on The Stanley Parable.  He thought back at all the good times he had with Stanley, the Narrator, and The Adventure Line.  But a thought crossed his mind, is it really a game?  The setting, story and dialogue are all there (with quite high quality voice acting even!), but what of the gameplay?  Is the mere act of movement enough of a world and pushing buttons, gameplay?James then realized the obvious: it did not matter.  What is important is the same thing that is important in all other games, the experiance.  As James looked over the hour's played count for The Stanley Parable, he noticed that he had poured hours into it, much of which were spent joyously listening to the narrator's witty remarks.James recommends the game highly.
