number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												A lot of people think that The Stanley Parable is a difficult game to describe, but I don't think it is that hard. It is a game about storytelling and player choice in video games. It is very aware of the fact that it is a video game, and there are many jokes about how games operate and the kinds of choices that you are allowed to make in them. As an avid story-based game player, I enjoyed the humor immensely. If this kind of meta-humor sounds at all interesting, go try out the demo. Even if you know you are going to buy the game, play the demo anyway because the content of the demo is not in the full game. Because this humor is really the core of the game, the more I tell you about the game, the less you will get out of it when you play it; it is best to discover everything for yourself. Therefore I want you to stop reading this review as soon as you are convinced to play the game. If you make it to the end and are still not convinced, then you and I have very different tastes and I don't know why you take my advice on anything entertainment related.A voice narrates your journey as you play as Stanley, an office worker who realizes that nobody is in the office building today. The narrator will tell you the path that Stanley took, but you are often free to try another path. The narrator will try to convince you to get back on track. At first he tries to rationalize why Stanley went the wrong way in the context of the story he is telling, but it doesn't take him long to break the fourth wall and address the player directly. There are many different branching paths in the game, but don't worry; the game starts back from the beginning when you get to the end of any of them.One of my favorite wall-breaking moments involved the broom closet above.The first time I played through, I tried to open every single door I came across. When the broom closet unexpectedly opened, I went inside. The narrator said, "Stanley went into the broom closet, but seeing that there was nothing in there he turned around and got back on track." So I did.The second time I went into the broom closet again, and the narrator said, "Seriously? I'm not even going to narrate this for you. Just do whatever it is you think is worth going into a broom closet for, and then let's get back to the story. I can wait."The third time the broom closet was boarded up. I laughed for a good 30 seconds.There were of course the mandatory jokes about office life, and how pointless meetings can be.If you defy the narrator enough times in one play through, the game world will start to deteriorate and the narrator will panic. That was a really fun thread.There is also a museum about the game and the creation of the game within the game. That was probably the most meta moment in the game.Then there was the time that the narrator tried to improve the game by adding more choices and global leader boards. He even decided to show you some other games that he did not make, namely Minecraft and Portal.Most of these are very silly, but some were much more serious and/or philosophical. In one Stanley thought he was in a dream, because that was the only explanation he could think of for all of the video game logic (he couldn't see his feet, the doors automatically closed behind him, etc.) In another Stanley died.Achievement hunting in The Stanley Parable is an absolute riot. Only a couple of the achievements are obtained through traditional means. Others are found in the main menu, or require you to exit the game and come back to it, or play throughout a Tuesday. Yeah, they're pretty intense.Seriously, you should go get The Stanley Parable, it will be the best two hours of your day. Even if you think the $15 price tag is too much for such a short game, you should at least check out the demo. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 22, 2014
												"Stanley walked through the RED door"-the NarratorI originally saw my favorite Youtuber named Markiplier play this game way back when it was a HL2 mod,then last year a stand-alone version of it was released on SteamAfter playing it myself,I can say that I love this game or at least the idea behind it(even tho I managed to beat it the same day I got it)The plot: There really isn't a"plot"since you can sort of make your own plot with all the possible endings the game gives you,but it mainly revolves around a man named Stanley who suddenly stops receiving commands from his computer,and as he wanders around the office(along with the Narrator who(somewhat)guides him),he notices some strange things happeningIn the game you don't necessarily have to listen to the Narrator,and in fact you can just completely ignore his directions altogether and go on your own path,or while you're letting him guide you,you can go on your own path,all of these things open up so many different possible endings,some of which I still haven't discovered yet.The music in this game is really good,especially that one piece of ambiance that plays in the beginning in Stanley's office and the music that plays while you're on the Adventure Line.The characters are really good,especially the Narrator with the funny dialogue he has.The different endings in this game were probably one of the best parts of the game because of the cool ideas behind them,especially the"Break The Game"ending(which I consider to be the true ending)Some of these endings were hilarious while some others just screw with your mind.(and in some cases,both)If you like games like Portal that are hilarious,but at the same time,mind-boggling,this is the game for you10/10 from me :)

content:
Posted: November 10, 2014
Clever writing, superb narration and meaningful satire prop up an otherwise weak game.As I sit here mulling over the meaning behind The Stanley Parable's parables I'm dismayed to find an overall depressing and pessimistic undercurrent. After playing all endings except the "Art Ending," I look at the big picture and it seems to me that the game is saying something along the lines of "Follow all of 'The Narrator's' commands or else something bad will surely happen to you." "The Narrator" being interchangeable with "The Man" or God or any authority figure. Even the "Heaven Ending" is twisted, albeit humorously, to be unappealing to the player.At a more surface level The Stanley Parable is parodying modern life, particularly work life, as well as video games themselves. It is here that the game shines and earns the praise it's received. I appreciate the jabs it takes at the mindless routines that consume much of our lives. Getting us to see our faults while simultaneously making us laugh is this game's greatest strength. However, as I stated in the previous paragraph, what happens within the game when you try to break out of the preset path seems to discourage the very same type of action that the game's satire encourages. This makes for a muddled message that makes me question the clarity and depth of the game. Perhaps I'm focusing too much on the real life issues when they meant it to be foremost a critique of modern game design where you often can't deviate substantially from the narrow narrative path.Excellent voice acting and witty comedy make the first few hours with the game very enjoyable. The way the game is designed to be replayed many times to explore different choices ultimately catches up with it as the repetition grows stale. To be fair, they did a lot to mitigate this by speeding up certain sections or by changing up what the Narrator says in successive playthroughs. It took me 5 hours to complete nearly everything the game has to offer (excluding 1 ending that requires 4 hours of ridiculous tedium). That time includes a significant amount of repetition and a short time on the web checking for any endings or achievements I had missed. Being that short I can't call this a good value for your gaming dollar. 6/10 and a weak "thumbs up."

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												It's pretty hard to tell what's this game about. Let me try not to spoil it for you... Well...This is a game about the honorable knight of a modern century. Stanley uses his power of thought to fight against the realms of forgotten human fears. The fears all of us have. Almost all of us. Stanley isn't afraid of our mere troubles, they're way too small for his thoughtful brain. He is a hero.Oh, the game, right. It takes place in space, where Stanley fights against demons disguised as giant stars. They will try  to seduce him, but we all know that this is impossible. Stanley cannot be controlled. He's the one controlling. He saves people and planets just on his own. Entire universe is fighting against him, but he will manage to strike back. He's a hero after all.But Stanley isn't one of the shining armor knights riding a white horse. He's close to our human beings. He has feelings. He sleeps, he laughs, he coughs, he frightens, he washes floors for free being a nice generous guy. See? He's just like you and me. He will never  give up trying to prove to this world being a perfect person who deserves this title.Levels? Who need them? The game runs perfectly well using two maps with giant attention to detail. Every piece of paper has it's own unique messages about Stanley being awesome. Every single chair has a bubblegum attached underneath. Even more: each gum has it's own flavor! Real revolution in game design will let you feel to be there, with Stanley.The story adjusts to your game style! It may be either fast-paced or slow walk on a park. Or maybe you will run across that park with bunch of sharks on your tail. Stanley doesn't have a tail like most of us. Another similarity! You're pretty much alike with Stanley! Except he does what he wants.But this game is not about what Stanley wants. This game is about what you want. You want to get another game where you play as a wizard,  because you want to be one, but simply can't. You want a game where you play as someone better than you. A game, where you can escape your daily routine and dive into a thriling adventure you will never get in your boring life. Stanley doesn't need neither you nor me nor anyone else. His story is perfect and complete.But you want to see it in action. Let all those puppets dance just for you. You were not even paying attention to what I was saying. It's a human nature to be maximally boring and minimally paying any attention to the matter of facts. I bet you can't wait to finish reading this very review to post a comment about both grammatical mistakes I've made, or maybe even about double spaces. Why are you reading this then? Most of you has already played the game and read this just to find some person to mock up because of his writing or spelling skills. Because none of you make mistakes. You're all perfect. Like Stanley is.

												Stanley is just an average guy with an average job, doing what he's been told. That is until he one day discovers that his coworkers have dissapeared. Confused and curious he begins to search the office for answers, while being narrated throughout his journey. But unfortunately for Stanley, the more he finds out, the more confused he becomes."The Stanley Parable" is an exploration of story, games, and choice (via thestanleyparable.com), It's a first person game where you play Stanley, leading him through his journey for answers. As the story goes by, Stanley is presented to different choices, and as he makes different choices during the game, the story develops in different ways."The Stanley Parable" explores a world with choices and consequenses. The fact that there's a "narrator" narrating Stanley's exploration might indicate that Stanley either is insane or maybe even that he doesn't have a real choice at all. The game is catchy and has quite a few "What ifs" that makes the player want to take a different path every time they play the game 10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												One of the best games of this decade, "The Stanley Parable" brilliantly makes of self reflection a raison d'être. More than introspection we should probably talk about what we can call "self extrospection".The game's self extrospection is favored by making the player bring up and reflect over all of those things that he (or she) considers being implicitly existing in some formats (that a videogame can be beaten, that there are good and bad choices to make, that enviromental interaction gives positive feedbacks, et cetera), and, on the base of those reflections, pushes him to consider the meaning of such conventions, their real value and, with a more distant perspective, his own relation to them and his acceptance of rules in general. One of the central arguing points of the game is that the player, by systematically trying to apply the same mechanics he is usually applying to videogames in order to achieve the results he is used to achieve, is substantially growing accustomed to mechanically do the same thing over and over, without demanding anything extra-ordinary (uncommon) of himself nor leaving any space for free reflection. "Stanley [...] has a job that demands nothing of him, and every button that he pushes is a reminder of the inconsequential nature of his existence. Look at him there: pushing buttons, doing exactly what he's told to do. Now, he's pushing a button. Now, he's eating lunch. Now, he's going home; now, he's coming back to work. One might even feel sorry for him, except that he's chosen this life." As Stanley is not questioning the repetitiveness of his job so the player might not be questioning certain patterns that he is automatically following in his gameplay sessions; in The Stanley Parable these patterns are usually bringing the player to look for something that he's used to get in other games, only to end up getting it in a very ridiculing form ( just think of the competitive leaderboards and the achievements ).In most of the cases, by giving the players exactly the contrary to what they wanted from the game, The Stanley Parable pushes the player to obtain a sort of third person self analytical perspective (even intensified in one of the endings in which  the game ends with a third person view on Stanley incapable of making a choice ), the so called (by me) "self extrospection", in which he is asked to reflect on the nature of his impulsive attractions or behaviours. The arising questions and the following thoughts are many: is what the players are looking for something really worth to look for, or are they just grown accustomed to have it and therefore they're feeling its absence when it's not given to them? But it is only when this perspective is moved to other entertainment forms, which are also demanding nothing of people and just drench them with a shower of positive or shocking stimuli, that we can really start to question the level of free will that we possess; as Gustave Le Bon writes in his book "The Crowd – A Study of the Popular Mind": ”It is only by obtaining some sort of insight into the psychology of crowds that it can be understood [...] how powerless they are to hold any opinions other than those which are imposed upon them, and that is not with rules based on theories of pure equity that they are to be led, but by seeking what produces an impression on them and what seduces them.” How much are we automatically doing because we've been pushed to grow accustomed to it? Are we laughing at a video where someone crashes with a motorbike because it is really funny and not at all unethical, or are we doing that to relief some of our personal frustrations by watching someone else failing? "Yes, it's all very amusing. And we laugh and we call our friends over and they laugh too and soon the whole world laughs and laughs and laughs at the man who failed. [...] But [...] you, sitting there: what have you gained watching this video? What have you learned?" And if we do it because of the frustrating monotony of our life, why are we then allowing the frustration to latently exist? Are we so accustomed to our life as it is that we're scared of doing any changes? How many non-influenced choices are we making? What's the worth of those choices? Stanley might be starting to understand all of this: "in and amongst his aimless meandering, I think he is actually beginning to discover something: he is getting closer to  an answer, an explaination, an exit. He is beginning to earn his freedom", but he is a videogame character bound to narrative limits and cannot escape his own story. He is Stanley and can only be Stanley. But what about us? "Now, if I could truly put you in his shoes, to show you the paths he walked and the choices he made.. [...] soon you will be the one to walk: the controls will be in your hands. [...] Oh, I think I'm going to enjoy this. When you find out how alone you truly are.. I will be laughing more than anyone."Is this a time in which we should break the old entertaining clichés of the videogame medium and release some of its pedagogical potential? Afterall "men never shape their conduct upon the teaching of pure reason" as Le Bon writes, and we can deduce that they learn by empirically experiencing reality. But if the virtuality is empirically making them experience and hate their own reality, isn't that potentially a formative experience? Is this then a case in which "ludus est magister vitae"?Well, it's certainly worth a thought.The Stanley Parable Personal ReviewRenzo "Stermayer" Arcuri

												Just when you thought you could just complete the game by getting across the doors and beating the final boss....well, wait, there isn't a boss, just doors and possibilities.So what choice will you make? Will you let the omniscient narrator take over your decisions, or will you fight off his control and follow your urges for freedom?In earnest, you should let this game take over your free will, immerse yourself in this predetermined world where you have no say whatsoever, where you can just follow instructions. Do not try to jump, do not open the broom closet, click on the photocopier, don't go downstairs, take the door on the right. Oh and Just go and buy this game on the steam store.WAIT! Did you just read this review and believe every word that was there? How could you blindly trust a random person writing a review and take up his advice to purchase something you would have no inclinations for? Yes, you are quite right, exercise your free will and DON'T buy this game. It has absolutely no bearing on your life and given the choice to ignore it, you should just forget about it.That's it, you did it, you are free now. But what's this? That little nudge in a corner of your head telling you: "what if...?". Indeed, what if you chose to get this game after all, and give it a try, to prove the world wrong, to show them that you can play it and follow your own footsteps...

content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												To describe anything about the game, that is to describe any scene that is going on in the game, any moment that stood out to me would be telling you too much. It would be too big a spoiler, no matter how insignificant the scene might seem. For nothing is really insignificant in the Stanley Parable. A butterfly flaps its wings and creates a hurricane, Stanley does something and chaos ensues.You can follow the narrator, or you can disobey him and watch what happens. What does happen would be a spoiler, however it leads to both hilarious dialogue and at the same time, somehow, without sacrificing comedy, it manages to make you think things over. It manages to question the nature of choice and free will. Are you truly free to do anything in the Stanley Parable? After all, the game has been predetermined, hasn't it? It has been built by a developer, and as such as a finite number of endings... But that's the thing, it never seems to end. Even after playing it for four hours straight, I had only found what, 7 endings? And I'm sure there's more to find, since I only explored the endings from the choices you were given, and I am told there are 18.Speaking of the narrator, you thought GLaDOS was good? This is basically GLaDOS on steroids. His voice is soothing, he is well written, and he has the right amount of intonation into everything he says, every line is delivered to perfection.The only complaint I could possibly have about the game is that it's on the short side, but that's good. It's like the original Portal, its length means that it doesn't overstay its welcome and that it keeps everything fresh.If I had to give it a number, I'd give it a solid 10 out of 10.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is an amazingly funny exploration game, with many different endings. It continually breaks the rules of video games in the most creative ways, and it manages to do this without becoming tedious or boring.Every individual ending is a completely different experience, from trying to defuse a bomb, to being lectured about the importance of your choices, to playing through different video games, all leaving you shocked and surprised as you play. You can never truly see what is going to happen.This, along with the excellent voice acting of the narrator makes an experience you wouldn't want to miss!The only downside, is that the game does not have much replay value, as once you have experienced an ending, you will never get the same feeling of surprise.Final Score: 9/10

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												The Stanley Parable is just one of those games which people either really like or really dislike; some may feel that they can't do much except freely roam around and listening to a guy talk. However, its beauty lies in the fact that it's entirely oriented about choice. It has some clever humor, and it is generally the type of game where you HAVE to try every single stupid action you can think of, in order to get a reaction from the narrator.Even if it's a bit short, The Stanley Parable is a great game. If you intend on buying it, I suggest that you try to learn the least possible about it or its story. I would also suggest to play the demo before buying the game (even if you are sure about your decision) : it will help you see if you like that kind of game or not, and it will also provide a good introduction to the actual game if you're going to buy it.The Stanley Parable is also best played with other people. and it requires a basic, general knowledge of first person video gaming in order to fully get its humor, in some moments.Have fun!

content:
Posted: November 6, 2013
												If you know a little bit about the Half-Life 2 modding scene, you may have heard of "The Stanley Parable", a critically acclaimed experiment by Davey Wreden from 2011. The free mod explores the theme of storytelling in video games: How does it work in this medium, when a player can determine what the character does, unlike the audience to a movie? How free can they be in their choices?Wreden has turned his (still recommendable) mod into a full game. Or, rather, "full" game, indie-style. Even when exploring every possible option, only 3 - 6 hours are what you can expect to get for your money (I have read of people spending more time on the game, but they may be revisiting the same places a lot more than me).But wait, what IS this thing anyway? The (new) Stanley Parable takes its model from the mod and expands it with more scenes. The main character Stanley works a dull office job, but one day he suddenly finds himself all alone in the complex and sets out to find out what happened. Stanley is played in classical FPS perspective, minus the gun. The special twist is that there is a narrator that accompanies him wherever he goes. The narrator makes sense of what Stanley encounters and tells the player what they are to do next. Whether you listen to him or not is entirely up to you - if you want to discover all that the game holds, it's even recommendable to not do everything he asks of you.According to your choices, Stanley will live, die, end up very confused, get stuck, have to sacrifice hours of his life in the service of art incarnate, ... I won't spoil it any further - the game is chock-full of wonderfully creative and funny ideas. Even going through the same area multiple times can reveal different things. If you like to explore, be surprised, prod at things to see what'll happen, or just goof around, this might be a game for you.Minor criticism: The mod's theme was quite clearly defined. This version is pretty much all over the place - while it is fun to play, I cannot really find a red line. Oh well. It taught me some things about myself, maybe that counts.Additional note: It's possible to create savegames, but that option is off by default. You need to activate it in the settings.

												A narrative experience like no other. You will no longer need sleep, instead you will think about Stanley, think about the meaning of modern videogames and ultimately start pondering over life itself. If you like food for your thoughts, this is a 12 course meal with dessert and free ice cream, it's simply that good. Don't rob yourself from one of the post narrative games in existence, join Stanley and the Narrator on an adventure and have your mind blown over 8888 times on this epic journey. When you're done, you can (and should BY ALL MEANS) start over again and choose a new branching path, ending and mind blowing experience.9.5/10  - More fun than I've had with any other game of this decade.

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Oh lord, what can be said about this game? The Stanley Parable is a gem, it really is. It's one of those games filled to the brim with sublte mystery and -fantastic- narration. Every path you take delivers witty dialogue, clever jokes, and an all-around, genuinely good time. As far as replayability is concerned, well, technically that's what this game is about--you've just got to find all the secrets and endings scattered around here and there, hoping to find something new, testing things you haven't tested before--pushing you to limits of clicking on just about everything--still, once you find satisfaction, picking up this game again might be challenging. For instance, I won't be playing this game for another five years in order to get a certain achievement, and no, I won't be resetting my clock to do so.

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												First of all, before purchasing the Stanley Parable, you should understand that this is only a "game" in the loosest sense, and you'll probably either love it or you just won't "get" it. You walk around, you occasionally press the "use" button on buttons and doors, and that's just about it. If you've tried Dear Esther or Gone Home, you can imagine that kind of experience, but where those games were far more serious and "artsy," The Stanley Parable is... something else. I don't want to spoil anything, and you should play the demo or watch the trailers to get an idea of the game's tone and the outstanding voice work of Kevan Brighting, if nothing else. That said, I loved every minute of the Stanley Parable, and though it is extremely short, there are multiple endings that all take the game in a completely different direction. If you want to laugh out loud, this is the game for you. Once you've seen everything there is to see, the game doesn't offer much replay value, but this is not an experience to be missed.

2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I have maintained the notion for a number of years that video games are pieces of art, just as viable as books, paintings, and sculptures--in some ways more so.  There are games that are eyeball-poppingly beautiful, of course, and games that make your brain cells implode--looking at you, Crysis 3 and Bioshock Infinite--but I have never before found a game that really made the player delve into their own psyche, a game that surpassed the boundaries of common narative functions and made the player the true star of the show.Thus enters this little game.  What can you do?  Walk around.  Sometimes, you interact with an object or two.  The only other being present is the brilliantly voiced narator.   Mostly, you walk, listen, walk some more, and listen some more.But, oh, that's the beauty of it.  Forget "gaming" mechanics, forget all the bells and whistles.  This game exists to get in your mind, where all the real action occurs.  It is a stunningly deep and riotously funny condiut for some of the most incredible glimpses of human nature I've had the pleasure of witnessing--via game or other media.  The Stanley Parable is a wonderful play for anyone with a sense of humor and a pension for self-examination.  This is a game about you--your importance, and your dispensibility, but even more so, about... well, I can't really say, lest I run the risk of spoiling the fun.  Pick this gem up.  10/10.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is quirky. Well, maybe quirky isn't the write word...witty? Ah, no, that doesn't seem right...It's a story. That's it! It's Stanley's story. It's the story of a man who works a job and who suddenly finds himself in the middle of a walking simulator.There are not many gameplay elements to The Stanley Parable. You really do spend your time walking, and maybe interacting a few times. The focus, rather, is on the humour and narrative of The Narrator, who will attempt to dictate your actions. Choice is a very big factor in this game, and you can choose to follow him or to be a rebel and go against his wishes. The Narrator's reactions are varied enough to make each walkthrough feel unique, and it's a joy to hear some of the wit and tongue-in-cheek meta humour written into the game itself. There are many endings, so replayability is quite good. Surprisingly, there was a rather dramatic moment in one of the endings, but for the most part this is a humorous game.I recommend purchasing this, as the writing alone is fantastic, and it is boosted by the wonderful voice acting.  If you're not into "walking sims", this may be a bit hard to get through for you, but the writing itself may take some of the edge off if it's your kind of humour. The price tag might be a little hefty for this kind of game, however it is well worth it if you can get it. As always, sales are the best so definitely pick it up on sale.Finally, there's a demo on Steam. What better way of finding out if it's for you than trying it out yourself? :)

content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
“This is a story of a man named Stanley”  Premise  In The Stanley Parable, the player takes on the role of a man simply named Stanley. Stanley’s job is just as simple as his name: an average everyday office worker. The only thing that sounds more boring than Stanley’s job and name, are his job requirements: press certain buttons as directed by a computer monitor. But don’t let this boring premise deter you from this game, it’s brilliant beyond measure.Despite sounding mindless, Stanley has a passion for his boring office job. Such a mindless passion, that when the orders stop coming in for him to press buttons from the monitor, he waits an entire hour beginning to question the lack of instruction. It’s this lack of instruction that causes Stanley to become self aware for the first time in his career (and possibly his life), and drives the beginning of the game. It also helps him notice other strange occurrences around the office and makes him ask questions. Where did my co-workers go? Did I miss a memo? Stanley finally has to make his own choices. He has to speak up. He has to think on his own. Where to I walk? What do I interact with? Stanley had been shielded from independent thinking his entire life it appears, all thanks to a computer monitor always telling him what to do. The choices and the independent thinking are where the finally player comes in, and where the excitement of the game is found. Or more accurately, the lack of choice is where the amusement is found. Mwahahahah. Ahem, carrying on.  Bulk of Review  Choices (and the lack of) are undoubtedly the cause of entertainment and humor in this game, but it’s the way these choices go hand-in-hand with the witty commentary that makes this game truly amusing. Wait, commentary? What commentary? I think it's a point of emphasis that I mention this a narration-driven game. When Stanley finally gains awareness, a narrator begins to narrate Stanley’s story audibly, remarking his thoughts and actions. The narrator is the one who woke up Stanley from his mindless slumber in the first place. He decides of what happens in the story just as much as the player does. Scratch that-- the narrator is an all powerful omnipotent being who limits the player in every thinkable way possible. That’s the point of the game in a nutshell.The thrill of the game is toying with the soothing narrator, who comments on every action and choice the player makes, or for that matter, refuses to make. The narrator not only makes comments, but directs and eventually commands Stanley to go down certain passageways and up certain staircases. He wants to control Stanley as much as you yearn to rebel against him. The true amusement is resisting and compromising with the narrator when he directs you to go down a hallway or through a door. In essence, that is the idea of the game. The struggle for control between the narrator of you and you-- No, not this door, I’ll go through this hallway instead. The narrator’s frustration and responses with his own character is hilarious and the most thought out part of this game.The game has very little visual feedback and reinforcement, which can be it’s downfall and it’s strength depending on the person. In most cases, I’d call it a strength. The player can only interact with a handful of objects, which are limited to doors, computers and buttons. This is what makes The Stanley Parable a breath of fresh air. For the first time in my gaming experience, a game relies on the majority of it’s feedback being audible instead of visual. That’s a strikingly new concept despite how simple it is to implement and carry out. If you like the Portal franchise or puzzle games like Antichamber, The Stanley Parable is comparable to a good mix of both, while still maintaining it’s own personality as a video game. The witty commentary and it’s amusement that comes with it draws an easy parallel between Portal and The Stanley Parable. If you like GLaDOS’s company, the game will do a excellent job of keeping you entertained. This game best caters to those who are willing to question everything in the room, and have an eye for patterns and details. The game has a total of 18 different endings depending on how you and the narrator get along, and how well you can think for yourself despite having limited alternatives to what the narrator says.  Some Criticism  So what is this game lacking? Choice. Despite the fact lack of choice is one of the key features of the game, it’s nonetheless a bit too limited. The vast majority of doors go unlocked and sometimes the player feels very forced into complying with the narrator. Of course, it’s worth noting the game itself is a analysis on the state of choice in video games. In video games as a medium, we are often more limited with our choices than we care to admit. The Stanley Parable makes light of this. We tend to accept the premise prematurely often too much. We blindly accept the number of choices that are presented, are the number of choices there are. Even with that being the case, the game needs more endings. 18 endings is great, but I feel there is a perfect threshold for this game to capture so it can still make it’s point about the lack of choice, and have more choice. Perhaps I’m sour I’ve completed the game and found all the endings, but hey, who wouldn’t want to rebel against an omnipotent soothing narrator a little more?  Conclusion  Currently, The Stanley Parable goes for a decent $15 on Steam. At best, it will give you 7 hours of gameplay if you’re sure to analyze every detail. For the average player however, 3 hours is what’s expected. Due to the nature of the game, it’s a rainy day experience. And while it has brilliant commentary and thought-provoking critique on the nature of choice in video games, $15 is a bit much for a day’s worth of entertainment. I’d strongly recommend waiting for a sale, but if you love Portal and soothing voices, I can empathize if you can’t.A Fair Recommendation - 8.7/10

content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												First of all, before purchasing the Stanley Parable, you should understand that this is only a "game" in the loosest sense, and you'll probably either love it or you just won't "get" it. You walk around, you occasionally press the "use" button on buttons and doors, and that's just about it. If you've tried Dear Esther or Gone Home, you can imagine that kind of experience, but where those games were far more serious and "artsy," The Stanley Parable is... something else. I don't want to spoil anything, and you should play the demo or watch the trailers to get an idea of the game's tone and the outstanding voice work of Kevan Brighting, if nothing else. That said, I loved every minute of the Stanley Parable, and though it is extremely short, there are multiple endings that all take the game in a completely different direction. If you want to laugh out loud, this is the game for you. Once you've seen everything there is to see, the game doesn't offer much replay value, but this is not an experience to be missed.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
												I have maintained the notion for a number of years that video games are pieces of art, just as viable as books, paintings, and sculptures--in some ways more so.  There are games that are eyeball-poppingly beautiful, of course, and games that make your brain cells implode--looking at you, Crysis 3 and Bioshock Infinite--but I have never before found a game that really made the player delve into their own psyche, a game that surpassed the boundaries of common narative functions and made the player the true star of the show.Thus enters this little game.  What can you do?  Walk around.  Sometimes, you interact with an object or two.  The only other being present is the brilliantly voiced narator.   Mostly, you walk, listen, walk some more, and listen some more.But, oh, that's the beauty of it.  Forget "gaming" mechanics, forget all the bells and whistles.  This game exists to get in your mind, where all the real action occurs.  It is a stunningly deep and riotously funny condiut for some of the most incredible glimpses of human nature I've had the pleasure of witnessing--via game or other media.  The Stanley Parable is a wonderful play for anyone with a sense of humor and a pension for self-examination.  This is a game about you--your importance, and your dispensibility, but even more so, about... well, I can't really say, lest I run the risk of spoiling the fun.  Pick this gem up.  10/10.

content:
Posted: January 17, 2014
												One of the best games of this decade, "The Stanley Parable" brilliantly makes of self reflection a raison d'être. More than introspection we should probably talk about what we can call "self extrospection".The game's self extrospection is favored by making the player bring up and reflect over all of those things that he (or she) considers being implicitly existing in some formats (that a videogame can be beaten, that there are good and bad choices to make, that enviromental interaction gives positive feedbacks, et cetera), and, on the base of those reflections, pushes him to consider the meaning of such conventions, their real value and, with a more distant perspective, his own relation to them and his acceptance of rules in general. One of the central arguing points of the game is that the player, by systematically trying to apply the same mechanics he is usually applying to videogames in order to achieve the results he is used to achieve, is substantially growing accustomed to mechanically do the same thing over and over, without demanding anything extra-ordinary (uncommon) of himself nor leaving any space for free reflection. "Stanley [...] has a job that demands nothing of him, and every button that he pushes is a reminder of the inconsequential nature of his existence. Look at him there: pushing buttons, doing exactly what he's told to do. Now, he's pushing a button. Now, he's eating lunch. Now, he's going home; now, he's coming back to work. One might even feel sorry for him, except that he's chosen this life." As Stanley is not questioning the repetitiveness of his job so the player might not be questioning certain patterns that he is automatically following in his gameplay sessions; in The Stanley Parable these patterns are usually bringing the player to look for something that he's used to get in other games, only to end up getting it in a very ridiculing form ( just think of the competitive leaderboards and the achievements ).In most of the cases, by giving the players exactly the contrary to what they wanted from the game, The Stanley Parable pushes the player to obtain a sort of third person self analytical perspective (even intensified in one of the endings in which  the game ends with a third person view on Stanley incapable of making a choice ), the so called (by me) "self extrospection", in which he is asked to reflect on the nature of his impulsive attractions or behaviours. The arising questions and the following thoughts are many: is what the players are looking for something really worth to look for, or are they just grown accustomed to have it and therefore they're feeling its absence when it's not given to them? But it is only when this perspective is moved to other entertainment forms, which are also demanding nothing of people and just drench them with a shower of positive or shocking stimuli, that we can really start to question the level of free will that we possess; as Gustave Le Bon writes in his book "The Crowd – A Study of the Popular Mind": ”It is only by obtaining some sort of insight into the psychology of crowds that it can be understood [...] how powerless they are to hold any opinions other than those which are imposed upon them, and that is not with rules based on theories of pure equity that they are to be led, but by seeking what produces an impression on them and what seduces them.” How much are we automatically doing because we've been pushed to grow accustomed to it? Are we laughing at a video where someone crashes with a motorbike because it is really funny and not at all unethical, or are we doing that to relief some of our personal frustrations by watching someone else failing? "Yes, it's all very amusing. And we laugh and we call our friends over and they laugh too and soon the whole world laughs and laughs and laughs at the man who failed. [...] But [...] you, sitting there: what have you gained watching this video? What have you learned?" And if we do it because of the frustrating monotony of our life, why are we then allowing the frustration to latently exist? Are we so accustomed to our life as it is that we're scared of doing any changes? How many non-influenced choices are we making? What's the worth of those choices? Stanley might be starting to understand all of this: "in and amongst his aimless meandering, I think he is actually beginning to discover something: he is getting closer to  an answer, an explaination, an exit. He is beginning to earn his freedom", but he is a videogame character bound to narrative limits and cannot escape his own story. He is Stanley and can only be Stanley. But what about us? "Now, if I could truly put you in his shoes, to show you the paths he walked and the choices he made.. [...] soon you will be the one to walk: the controls will be in your hands. [...] Oh, I think I'm going to enjoy this. When you find out how alone you truly are.. I will be laughing more than anyone."Is this a time in which we should break the old entertaining clichés of the videogame medium and release some of its pedagogical potential? Afterall "men never shape their conduct upon the teaching of pure reason" as Le Bon writes, and we can deduce that they learn by empirically experiencing reality. But if the virtuality is empirically making them experience and hate their own reality, isn't that potentially a formative experience? Is this then a case in which "ludus est magister vitae"?Well, it's certainly worth a thought.The Stanley Parable Personal ReviewRenzo "Stermayer" Arcuri

Posted: April 1, 2015
												This is my review of The Stanley Parable, which I definitely played.The Stanley Parable is a computer game. It is available for $14.99.Its genre (as the French say) is definitely first-person exploration.The game is set in an office, but sometimes it's not.The parable in the game is about Stanley.The graphics are very white, and black. Sometimes it is blue, though. There are also some shades of red. Blue is an awesome color.There’s a part where you see a guy in a white coat typing at a desk. I still don’t know who that is, but that’s okay. There’s also a brown sofa and a table with empty glasses on it, plus tall shelves of books, as well as a portrait of a suit and two hands. There’s also this part where you get to see two doors with numbers on them, and another desk with a number beside it.Is the game hard? Well, maybe. I mean, some people say Super Meat Boy is easy, while I find Super Meat Boy Super Hard. As for MY experience with the Stanley Parable, I’d say it was maybe hard, but you might find it easy.I am Very Positive that this game is good. Overall I give it a 92% rating, plus or minus one percent.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												A very short game... If you're a sheep.This game is very special, you can spend as much as 4 minutes and a bit or a few hours on this game. It's a kind of game that plays with the illusion of choice. What this game does is that it takes the 4th Wall, straps 20lbs of C4 to it, adds a sprinkle of thermite and lets it rip. But wait it ain't done with the 4th Wall yet oh no. It then fires 163613 jackhammers out of a cannon and a squirrel at it until that wall ceases to exist anymore. Donald Trump doesn't stand a chance against this game.You play as Stanley, or should I say "Employee No. 427". You sit in front of your 1980's era DOS interface CRT monitor and wait for instructions on which buttons to push on the keyboard. You are one of a plethora of generic employees who work for a corporation. What kind of corporation? I still have no clue. It kinda reminds me of the "1984" ad by Apple for their Macintosh.You are given instructions to follow by the narrator (a very amusing narrator I may add) of the game, but listening and conforming to those instructions is up to you, which also mean the consequences that follow for each instruction followed (or should I say not followed) are your responsibilty. It seems extremely linear at first, but once you realise you are the one controlling Stanley and not the narrator, the possibilities are endless.I aqcuired this game in the Summer Steam Sale for €2.39.Is it worth it? YesIs it up to you to decide if it is? Abso-****ing-lutelyMy rating? 7.5/10

												Oh lord, what can be said about this game? The Stanley Parable is a gem, it really is. It's one of those games filled to the brim with sublte mystery and -fantastic- narration. As far as replayability is concerned, well, technically that's what this game is about--you've just got to find all the secrets and endings scattered around here and there, hoping to find something new, testing things you haven't tested before--pushing you to limits of clicking on just about everything--still, once you find satisfaction, picking up this game again might be challenging. For instance, I won't be playing this game for another five years in order to get a certain achievement, and no, I won't be resetting my clock to do so.

content:
Posted: March 25, 2016
The Stanley Parable is a farce.Originally posted by Wikipedia:In theatre, a farce is a comedy that aims at entertaining the audience through situations that are highly exaggerated, extravagant, and thus improbable. Farces are often highly incomprehensible plot-wise (due to the many plot twists and random events that occur), but viewers are encouraged not to try to follow the plot in order to avoid becoming confused and overwhelmed. [...] A farce is also often set in one particular location, where all events occur.Now let's speak in practical terms. TSP is technically a walking simulator. There is not much interaction beyond opening doors and pressing buttons. The game is about walking through different locations and exploring different scenarios.Of couse, TSP is much more than that, or it wouldn't have been the focus of so many articles in the gaming press, or have so many positive reviews everywhere (as here on Steam.)TSP is a deconstruction of structural narratives in gaming. It is best appreciated by gamers who've played plenty of scripted games, wondered at all about how such experiences are designed, or have become wise to the patterns and framework that hold a game narrative together.This mostly translates to you, the player, defying (or obeying) the narrator's instructions and seeing how that goes.Of course, those defiances and their effects are, in the end, just as scripted as the rest of the game. And the game is aware of it, deconstructing even that. Is your head spinning yet?All this to say that this is a very enjoyable, clever, funny experience. The narrator is brilliant in his delivery. The different branches and endings keep you interested for far longer than you'd expect. And I would suggest you resist the urge to go online and look at the game's unofficial wiki. Try to find as many paths and endings as you can, alone. Most are easy to find. Some are hidden.Is this game for you? If you've ever thought about how game stories are put together, then yes it is.

content:
Posted: August 17, 2015
												$14.99 seems like a lot for a game. And yes, in most cases I'd agree with you. However, there are some circumstances in which paying what feels like more-than-average is entirely okay. This is one of those cases.The Stanley Parable is one of the most original, creative, and though-provoking games (or THINGS, for that matter) I've ever played. Once you finish it, you've finished it. You can go back and do everything as many times as you want, but once you've done it, you've done it.And that's okay.I've played this game for about 6 hours (at the time of review) and while I've done pretty much everything there is to do, I've spent hours in reflection of what any of it means. You will learn from this game if you allow yourself to.It can be silly. It can be unsettling. Most importantly, it can be touching.I cannot recommend this game highly enough. If you're on a budget, waiting wouldn't hurt, but if its on sale for as cheap as it gets (I think around $3.75?), there's no reason not to buy it.I love this game, and it's made its way into my list of favorites with ease.P.S. If you don't like the fact that there is (for the sake of this review) no action, and you don't want to spend time listening to the narration, I do NOT recommend it. Its VERY VERY good, yes, but it may not be what some people consider 'fun' (although I presonally had BLAST with it).

												8/10Not sure where to start with this review, but I will say this: this game messes with your mind! In terms of mechanics, this game is incredibly simple. It is a walking simulator set in a bland office building. But, in a game like this, mechanics and visuals really don't matter. For this little game, all you need to worry about is the satirical narrator and your choices.The Stanley Parable is an extremely peculiar but hilarious game. The humor is witty and sarcastic, and on occasion, can be rather dark. Also, forget the fourth wall in this one; it is practically nonexistent. Of course, we have the narrator to thank for that. He is extremely reactive to the player's behavior and will comment on the strangest things. (Get the Door 430 achievement; that's one of the best pieces of commentary in the game!) However, he also has some moments where he will either rail on the player in a fierce rant, or seriously guilt trip him/her in a somewhat dejected manner. These rapid changes in his dialogue can be a little disarming but give the narrator more depth as a character (if that is how you see him), thus having the potential to affect the way you play the game.Despite its fantastic humor, the game's primary focus is on its philosophical topics. Most of the time, those topics dance around in the background and are alluded to by the narrator. Where the really shine is in the "endings". Each one, no matter how quirky or funny, has some sort of message to convey. Some, as would be expected in this type of game, focus on the nature of choices, and whether or not they matter. Others may touch on subjects such as the meaning of life or one's perception of reality. These "endings" can be incredibly thought-provoking and deep; one in particular left me staring at my computer for about 15 minutes in contemplative shock. And, when I describe it as a shock, it's not hyperbole.Of course, what you get out of said endings is completely up to you. How will you interpret the endings and what the narrator has to say about them?So, to sum it all up, The Stanley Parable is an extremely clever and philosophical game that is sure to keep the player's attention all the way through(?). It is one of those special games that can give you both memorable laughs and the occasional existential crisis! Enjoy!

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
												Truly amazing. I wrote a review of the Demo and the original mod before the full game came out awhile back and never got around to writing a review for this one, but I can say that this was well worth the $15. For those who played the original, know that it is not just an HD remix of the original Source mod. It also adds plenty of new endings, as well as new secrets. The original made it quite obvious to the player the choices available and the amount of endings that could be had, but now they've changed plenty of things around to add more secrets, endings, and oh, the replayability!Now, every time you finish the game, the game will begin again and sometimes after certain endings certain things will change, and it has some hilarious achievements, such as playing the game for the entire duration of a Tuesday, or not playing for five years, or the "Unacheivable" acheivement (which is apparently somehow acheivable but I'm not sure how to legitly yet).I definitely recommend this game to EVERYONE.PS: Don't look up any videos or any information about it. It's best experienced first-hand; there's a reason the Store page tells you nothing about the game. If you aren't prepared to throw your money around without knowing about it, play the Demo. Actually—either way, play the demo first. It has exclusive content from the actual game and is hilarious in its own right–it's the best Demo ever, such a good Demo that I wrote a review of the demo.... yeah.If that's not enough for you, you can play the original mod if you want. It's on Desura and IndieDB for free–you don't need Half-Life 2, just the Source SDK Base 2007 will do it.I rate this game 8.8888 Stanleys out of 8.8888

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is quirky. Well, maybe quirky isn't the write word...witty? Ah, no, that doesn't seem right...It's a story. That's it! It's Stanley's story. It's the story of a man who works a job and who suddenly finds himself in the middle of a walking simulator.There are not many gameplay elements to The Stanley Parable. You really do spend your time walking, and maybe interacting a few times. The focus, rather, is on the humour and narrative of The Narrator, who will attempt to dictate your actions. Choice is a very big factor in this game, and you can choose to follow him or to be a rebel and go against his wishes. The Narrator's reactions are varied enough to make each walkthrough feel unique, and it's a joy to hear some of the wit and tongue-in-cheek meta humour written into the game itself. There are many endings, so replayability is quite good. Surprisingly, there was a rather dramatic moment in one of the endings, but for the most part this is a humorous game.I recommend purchasing this, as the writing alone is fantastic, and it is boosted by the wonderful voice acting.  If you're not into "walking sims", this may be a bit hard to get through for you, but the writing itself may take some of the edge off if it's your kind of humour. The price tag might be a little hefty for this kind of game, however it is well worth it if you can get it. As always, sales are the best so definitely pick it up on sale.Finally, there's a demo on Steam. What better way of finding out if it's for you than trying it out yourself? :)

content:

												A pretty fun and unusual game. It's mostly a parody on certain mechanics used in games, most notably the idea of player choice. Throughout the entire time, there is a narrator speaking to the player, who is trying hard to guide the player along a certain direction. The player can then choose to listen to the narrator or wander off and do what they feel like, which gets on narrator's nerves.There isn't all that much content in the game, and I kind of wish it had more, but what is there is certainly worth experiencing. The game is both funny and thought-provoking. "Now, Stanley, let's go and find the story." :D

content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
												Oh lord, what can be said about this game? The Stanley Parable is a gem, it really is. It's one of those games filled to the brim with sublte mystery and -fantastic- narration. Every path you take delivers witty dialogue, clever jokes, and an all-around, genuinely good time. As far as replayability is concerned, well, technically that's what this game is about--you've just got to find all the secrets and endings scattered around here and there, hoping to find something new, testing things you haven't tested before--pushing you to limits of clicking on just about everything--still, once you find satisfaction, picking up this game again might be challenging. For instance, I won't be playing this game for another five years in order to get a certain achievement, and no, I won't be resetting my clock to do so.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
												First of all, before purchasing the Stanley Parable, you should understand that this is only a "game" in the loosest sense, and you'll probably either love it or you just won't "get" it. You walk around, you occasionally press the "use" button on buttons and doors, and that's just about it. If you've tried Dear Esther or Gone Home, you can imagine that kind of experience, but where those games were far more serious and "artsy," The Stanley Parable is... something else. I don't want to spoil anything, and you should play the demo or watch the trailers to get an idea of the game's tone and the outstanding voice work of Kevan Brighting, if nothing else. That said, I loved every minute of the Stanley Parable, and though it is extremely short, there are multiple endings that all take the game in a completely different direction. If you want to laugh out loud, this is the game for you. Once you've seen everything there is to see, the game doesn't offer much replay value, but this is not an experience to be missed.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2013
												A high-quality remake (including more content) of the original title with the same name. It's a sort of choose-your-own-adventure with narration. A typical play-through is probably about 5 to 15 minutes, depending on the choices you take. The game is designed to be replayed multiple, multiple times. Awesome narration, clever humor and writing. I spent time looking at everything, and doing all the obvious choices that are presented, then looked up the additional ones and went through those. Took me about 3-4 hours to do so. Highly recommend this game, as well as the demo (which is completely new content, due to the nature of this game.) The original HL2 mod is also really good, but dated.

content:

												Incredibly unique.  Addictive not in the traditional "gotta level up" sense, but more of an exploration type of addictive.  This game breaks the "fourth wall" in a few aspects, and there's honestly way, way, way more than what the eye sees.  If this game was an iceberg, maybe 5% of it is on the surface.I've maybe played 2 hours or so, but I've pretty much just been exploring and seeing what options = what outcome.  Also, soaking in the level design, which is AMAZING might I say.I got this during the half off sale for $7.50.  Very well worth it at that price.  At full price, maybe, if I knew exactly how much content there was.  I usually expect about 1 hour of entertainment for every $1 USD I spend.  The other qualities of this game make up for it if this falls short of that expectation, though.  So if you're thinking about it, do it, especially if you're a fan of Source engine based games.

content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Great game! Funny, interesting, and involving.Basic Gameplay:You are Stanley, an ordinary employee (number 427) in an ordinary office building. One day, you are pushing buttons at your desk when you realize no one else is there. Your life is narrated by "The Impeccable Kevan Brighting." I won't say anything else for fear of spoilers, but here's my Pro/Con list:PROS:+ Engaging gameplay+ Easy controls+ Wonderful, interesting storyline+ 19 possible endings+ New, unique idea+ The narrator+ Small changes with each playthrough+ Fun Easter eggs and jokes if you take your timeCONS:- Gets repetitive- When you exhaust all endings, there isn't much more contentOverall, I highly recommend this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												The End is Never The End is Never The End is Never the End...Where to start with The Stanley Parable?  For 15$ dollars, I played the game for only a few hours.  Was it worth my money?  Was it worth my time?  It's hard to say.  Did I enjoy it?  Certainly so, but will you, the reader enjoy it?  There's only one way to find out and play it for yourself.It's hard to write about a game like The Stanley Parable.  The entire game is comprised of decisions.  You walk around, choose a path, and listen to some dialogue.  Sound boring?  Except the narrator has some of the most witty dialogue since GLaDoS and his humor really rubs you the right way.  The game is wrapped up in metaphors and sarcasm and open to interpretation.  It's up to you, the player, to decide what truly happens at the end of the day.  Yes there are set endings, but it's up to you to give them meaning.  Even after I got all the endings, I found myself still playing it to find the small secrets.  It's rare that I touch a game after beating it (unless nostalgia calls), but I really just wanted more.  I wanted to hear the narrator more.  I wanted to see what little gems the developers had thrown in.While this review may have just made you more confused, just buy it.  Don't go to YouTube and watch some videos, don't stare at your computer screen and ponder about the question, just buy it.  It's 15$ may be a bit steep, but it's a philosophical journey that I enjoyed.TL:DR - An artsy type of game that isn't pretentious or dumb.  Filled with emotional bits that make you think.

content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												The Stanley Parable is just one of those games which people either really like or really dislike; some may feel that they can't do much except freely roam around and listening to a guy talk. However, its beauty lies in the fact that it's entirely oriented about choice. It has some clever humor, and it is generally the type of game where you HAVE to try every single stupid action you can think of, in order to get a reaction from the narrator.Even if it's a bit short, The Stanley Parable is a great game. If you intend on buying it, I suggest that you try to learn the least possible about it or its story. I would also suggest to play the demo before buying the game (even if you are sure about your decision) : it will help you see if you like that kind of game or not, and it will also provide a good introduction to the actual game if you're going to buy it.The Stanley Parable is also best played with other people. and it requires a basic, general knowledge of first person video gaming in order to fully get its humor, in some moments.Have fun!

I'm writing a positive review instead of a negative one though because I have recently changed my mind. I have gone through almost every single ending this game has to offer (which is quite a few). Anyway I'm in the game right now standing in a broom closet, in which I've been in this broom closet for fifteen minutes so far laughing my butt off. That is what this game has done to me.

2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												A lot of my friends have asked why I play video games at my age and with my job...Well, The Stanley Parable is one of the reasons.This game epitomises what gaming is about for me: it doesn't follow the usual formula at all, was made cheaply, easily and quickly, and features oodles of surprises and treats that aren't thrown in your face.Games like these represent what is so powerful about Steam and PC gaming in general: we don't have to put up with generics.  We have a slew of (cheap) unique games at our fingertips, and we would be foolish not to take full advantage of that.But, onto the game itself.  How to describe it? Imagine Fight Club, I suppose, if instead of Tyler Durden, the Narrator met Milton (from Office Space).  And then took acid.  And this was all narrated by the Monty Python crew.See, that's the real beauty of this game: the banality of the concept (an office worker) is offset by a message not unlike Fight Club (minus - mostly - the violence) and painted with a distinctly meta feel to it.It's the juxtaposition that really makes the concept of this game shine: our protaganist's apparently choiceless, linear line is thrown wide open (with, well, bizzare scenarios at times) by telling us we are not free to choose his ending...and then giving us the opportunity to do the exact opposite.I had moments where I was chuckling for a while, shaking my head at the absurdity of it all. Other times I burst out laughing.  Still other situations had me stopping to pause, genuinely questioning the implications of an event and how it related to my life."Ah, but the cons," you say, and rightly so.  Well, it does feel short.  Which is a concern when it's so easy to pick up cheaper games that last (a lot) longer.  I would very much recommend that you wait for a big sale for this game, particularly if your budget is constrained. To put it into perspective: I reckon (without giving away spoilers) that I've discovered more or less everything there is, and I don't have much time invested into the game.TL;DR: a recommended game, a brilliant story, but not a game that will keep you coming back for more hours later.

content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												Well, this is a new one. A First Person game where there is no shooting or puzzle solving. Mainly just making choices and exploring every area is what this game is all about. I enjoyed the comedic dialogue of the narrator and the strange endings that transpire depending on the different decisions you make. It had alot of confusing moments as rooms tend to change each time you come to a dead end. Even though everything seemed pretty random, alot of scripted dialogue was put into the game and possiblities were many but still I feel there should have been more. But I haven't made a game so I could not do any better than this. For the price I paid for it, it was nice and fun to play. I think I enjoy more the reaction I get from having my friends and family play it. I definitely enjoyed markiplier's commentary while he played the game. This is a fun game to experience once and then have your loved ones play as well.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												    There, more or less, is no such thing as a good, spoiler-free review of this game. After all, what makes this game so ridiculously ingenious, darkly comical and chillingly haunting can only re/ally be captured within examples from the dynamic and somehow engaging tale. Plus, most of what the story is about is discovered over time and unraveled throughout the game. I'll do my best all the same.    You are cast into an eerily vacant office space, full of mystery and the echoes of an ironic and altogether fitting British man giving you orders by means of telling your story, before it actually happens. I won't give too much detail for fear of ruining it, but there often is a choice. Follow what you are told, or revolt against what you are told. It is up to you. I won't say any more. You need to find out for yourself.    Although very short (completed in one and a half hours), this game captures emotion and pyscological elements in an indescribably unique way, and is an experience that cannot be missed. 9/10, absolutely astounding. Prepare for profuse mind blowing.

content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
												I'm a little torn when I try to rate The Stanley Parable. It is not really a game I would say. I mean, in a way it is: you control a character move, press buttons, but that's pretty much it, in terms of 'playing' the game. It is more of an experience, a little bit pleasant, a little bit masochistic. One worth going through, for sure.Stanley Parable leaves one confused. You will never know, if you have gotten to the ending yet. Actually, there really is no ending at all. Or maybe there is, I don't know.I will tell you what it will do to you though. It WILL make you change your mind often. It WILL make you notice tiny, little details change, when entering the same room for the 50th time and it WILL leave you trying to figure out, if that change will eventually lead to another part of the game. It WILL leave you in a janitor's closet for at least 10 minutes and it WILL make you listen to the narrator mock you for sitting there for the whole time. It WILL try to kill you. It WILL make you kill yourself. It WILL kill you. It WON'T kill you. It WILL lead you to heaven. It WILL make you push buttons, or not...The only real problem with Stanley Parable is that it's too short.  Because who wouldn't like to walk through empty corridors for a tiny bit longer, while being mocked of and insulted by someone who controls you?Some people say they would like to have Morgan Freeman as a narrator of their life, I would prefer to leave this job to the narrator of The Stanley Parable.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2015
												The Stanley Parable is a first person exploration game developed by Galactic Cafe on the source engine. It follows a regular office worker named "Stanley" (whose job it is to push buttons on a keyboard) after all of his co-workers mysteriously disappear, and he starts to hear the voice of a mysterious narrator in his head.The Stanley Parable is at it's core an expermiment in player choice and how that effects gaming as a story-telling medium. It doesn't have any fancy butterfly effects it actually plays out more like a choose-your-own adventure book with preset paths and endings. With the player activating triggers by making choices that lead down branching paths toward one of a variety of endings.Beyond that core is a commentary on gaming and the medium that games present to a player, involving a main character with no personality beyond literally being the player, and a narrator (voiced by Kevan Brighting) who acts as a standin for the video game's developers. This story choice and meta commentary is neatly wrapped in surreal humor and wit, with the interplay between the players choices and the narrator's opinion on those choices being the focal-point of the experience, as well as the ultimate selling point of the advertisments. Yes, the narrator getting increaingly angrier the more you choose paths that don't lead to his prefered ending is a neat little cherry on top, but the humor also branches off into a variety of paths, involving anything from absurdly dark humor to surrealist nonesense and everything in between, it truley is a fascinating and involving group of experiences, that is worth the pricetag even in the face of how little guns you can use to shoot monsters and nazis.And if that doesn't have you sold, than the phrase 'Drugs and Hookers' is used in bitter spite at one point. Go figure out when.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 3, 2015
												Taking directions in video games has become something we've all (generally) become resigned to; we read the manual, check out the controls menu, follow signs and hints in the environment, etc... In most cases, games follow a guideline and set limitations as to what extent you can deviate from the original plan or script, these rules becoming more lenient and expanded since the good ol' days of the NES and into the realms of MMOs and open-world exploration based titles. Still, seldom are you punished or scolded directly for wandering off the intended route; you may be given a time limit to return to the battlefield, come across enemy mobs too strong for you, or usually be met with an invisible wall or impenetrable barricade that artificially confines you. The Stanley Parable explores taking directions in rather clever ways, and while the game does have an impact regarding your choices, it tackles the subject from an angle of entertainment and comedy with less focus on inquisitive examination, and while I walked away relatively pleased in the end,  I was left hoping for a bit more education.The Stanley Parable is a game based on player choices and how a story can change accordingly, these changes being delivered and addressed by the narrator, Kevan Brighting, whose voice work is a highlight of the game. Brighting delivers all of his lines with a certain eloquence and gentlemanly grace, despite the range of moods he goes through as Stanley, the titular protagonist (and arguably antagonist, but we'll get to that later), shuffles along on his adventures. While the narrator doesn’t break his calm, reserved character despite your decisions, there are points where he has to become menacing, pleading or so sarcastically dry he could melt a glacier, and said eloquence is kept even throughout all these scenes. Since Brighting's voice is the one that guides you through the game's various routes, the fact his work is so clean, clear and best of all pleasant to listen to makes him a wonderful addition to a game that would've otherwise been about wandering aimlessly around.What intrigued me the most about The Stanley Parable was the Molyneux-esque aspect of the player being able to make choices that impact your progress. When you first start the game you're given an opening monologue about Stanley's job and how it's a heavily directed job with instructions coming to him via computer, but soon his incoming directions cease and he discovers that he's all alone in the office, and then the player takes control of Stanley. The narrator then tells the story about Stanley exploring his empty office, and eventually you come across two open doors; the narrator says that Stanley goes through one of them. If you follow the script, the story continues along giving you other chances to deviate from the intended script and the narrator will react accordingly. Following the script one hundred percent to the letter will have you completing the game in no time at all, rewarding you with a rather positive, if not insidious, ending... That is, if you follow the script. Let's rewind back to the first major choice Stanley has of entering door number one or door number two, and how the narrator dictates that Stanley chooses one, not the other - Or does he? Does he have to? The other door is there, wide open and leading somewhere else. The only thing stopping you from making Stanley go through the other door is what the narrator just said. There's a sense of mischief and empowerment of being able to deny the script and do what you please, even if your routes are clearly defined and refusing to follow said script makes you a nuisance more than an obnoxious rebel.This brings me back to the point of Stanley being both the protagonist and antagonist, depending on your choices. Regardless of whether you play nice or forge your own path, the story has to reach a conclusion, the narrator taking on different roles depending on your chosen route; he may resign in helplessness, be as confused as you are when assets being loaded in don’t fit the script or function, and he even becomes hostile and threatening when he tires of the foolishness. The different ways the story has to adapt to your decisions is the big draw and appeal to the game, but the massive flaw in The Stanley Parable is that once you go through a route and reach its ending, there is no point in going back to it. In fact once you find every possible ending in the game, there is practically no point in returning to it, unless you want to uncover each piece of the narrator's lines, find secrets or cash in on the achievements. Even then The Stanley Parable is quick to run out of things to do, giving it poor lasting power - Including some clowning around, I reached each ending, which had me clocked in at just over three hours when all was said and done. That's really the only thing that severely hampers the game, but at the same time I'm thankful that artificial time padding was omitted for a game that gets you in, offers up comedy and an incredibly well written and expertly voice acted script, then gets you out. The Stanley Parable certainly is not a replayable title, but as mentioned the lessons it teaches while being witty keeps it from overstaying its welcome and becoming a bore. I was amused and intrigued during my time with it, but I wished at times that the game was more informative to the player in an educational or logical sense along with its entertainment. For example, your choices have an impact on the narrator and the script, and because the story must reach an end, changes have to be made accordingly. While the results end up amusing, I had hoped there would’ve been a closer, deeper look on the matter from a game design standpoint. Of course, it’s a game about a man with a charming English accent narrating another man’s eventual subterfuge of the story, so intelligent, lengthy discussions on game design is not its goal. That said, if you're at all interested in logic and game design then The Stanley Parable is certainly worth your time, but only if the lack of major replayability doesn't have you turned off.
