content:
Posted: July 2, 2015
												The Stanley Parable is a first person story-driven adventure game that will amuse and bemuse you. As you wander though the office, looking for your missing colleagues, the game's mood and environment shifts in diverse, drastic, and impactful ways depending on the choices that you make. This fluid design will toy with your established expectations of how video games should function and progress.All of this is guided by the highlight of the game: its narration, which can morph from hilarious to poignant in seconds as the game reacts to your decisons. One minute you're giggling as the narrator is trying to find "the story", the next you're questioning whether there was ever real choices in the game, or if you truly have freedom in your own life. And to top it off, the game has multiple, and extremely different, endings that encourage replayability and leave you astonished every time. A thoughtful and well constructed adventure (in the truest sense), The Stanley Parable is a great game that will hopefully leave you as flabbergasted and pleased as I was when I was done with it.

Posted: October 18, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is one of those special games that burst everyone's bubble.Who is Stanley and why is he pushing the same buttons over and over because he is told to through a computer monitor? Well, enter The Stanley Parable where the narrator changes Stanley's life forever. In The Stanley Parable, there is no clear or concise story, you make your own story, at least from the handful of endings that are available. But you really don't know what the story is because there isn't exactly any. Is happiness a conspiracy? Well, there's no leaving the office building Stanley works at, so it's a possiblity. Some of the endings will drive you mad but make you laugh. The rest of the endings will make you cry and make you sad and depressed; because when you've beaten every ending, including the art ending.....Stanley becomes the useless protagonist.9.1/10

content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is a refreshing experience within the occasionally lackluster indie game scene. You will find no riveting plot or uncover any mysterious consipracies, as screenshots and trailers may suggest. The beauty of The Stanley Parable is that it plays, and perhaps even teases you, on what your expectations of video games are in the 21st century, and the way you interact with the in-game world. It is good to spend a few hours trying to uncover the various paths one can take to progress through the game, and discovering that it might not be fit to hold the title of "game" at all. Overall if you are looking for a short and interesting indie title, you should try out the Stanley Parable.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												i love kind of games like this cuz they have infinite possibilitys!! and i love easter eggs!!! here's my discription of the stanley parable and a few facts!!!The Stanley Parable is an interactive fiction modification (mod) built on the Source game engine, developed by Davey Wreden and released in July 2011. A high-definition remastered stand-alone version, including new story elements, was developed by Wreden and Source modeler William Pugh under the Galactic Cafe development team name. The remake was announced and approved via the Steam Greenlight process in 2012, and released in October 2013 for Microsoft Windows and December 2013 for OS X.While both the mod and the remake use the first-person perspective common to other Source engine mods, there are no combat or other action-based sequences. Instead, the player controls the protagonist, Stanley, through a surreal environment, with each step of the process narrated, voiced by British actor Kevan Brighting. The player has the opportunity to make numerous decisions on which paths to take, including going against what the narration is telling them to do, each choice leading to different narrations and endings. Wreden envisioned the game after considering that most major video game titles confine the user to its rules, and considered how to construct a narrative to challenge that notion. Outside of Brighting's voice work of the narrator, Wreden built the modification himself, initially as a personal project for his career goals but soon expanding to a wider release once he had shown it to friends and other players. The modification received critical attention as a new variation of creating interactive fiction within a game engine, and provided a thought-provoking narration to discuss with others on the nature of choice and predestination within video games.The remake grew out the experience, recreating many of the original mod's decisions within new environments while adding several more story pathways that could be followed. The standalone game has received similar critical praise from journalists favoring the expanded narrative and commentary on player choice and decision-making in modern video games.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2015
												It truly is hard to put this game into words. At first it may seem like a simple game, you walk, go where you are told, and finish the game. But after a bit of playing, you start to find new ways to play the game, and find it to be much larger than you first imagined. It now seems to be a fun little game, with some silly moments, biting insults, and multiple endings. But as you play the game even more, you start to notice even more things. Like that as you were playing the game, the game was playing you. Every decision you make is manipulated by the game. From the first time you escaped, to your rebellious decision to take the door on the right, to every playthrough after that. You don't play this game, the game plays you.Eventually you notice something amazing. This isn't even a game. The name states that. It's something much greater than just a game, it's a parable. A parable is a story told to teach a moral lesson. I think this game makes a great parable. But, what lesson does it teach? You'll have to play to find out.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												A lot of my friends have asked why I play video games at my age and with my job...Well, The Stanley Parable is one of the reasons.This game epitomises what gaming is about for me: it doesn't follow the usual formula at all, was made cheaply, easily and quickly, and features oodles of surprises and treats that aren't thrown in your face.Games like these represent what is so powerful about Steam and PC gaming in general: we don't have to put up with generics.  We have a slew of (cheap) unique games at our fingertips, and we would be foolish not to take full advantage of that.But, onto the game itself.  How to describe it? Imagine Fight Club, I suppose, if instead of Tyler Durden, the Narrator met Milton (from Office Space).  And then took acid.  And this was all narrated by the Monty Python crew.See, that's the real beauty of this game: the banality of the concept (an office worker) is offset by a message not unlike Fight Club (minus - mostly - the violence) and painted with a distinctly meta feel to it.It's the juxtaposition that really makes the concept of this game shine: our protaganist's apparently choiceless, linear line is thrown wide open (with, well, bizzare scenarios at times) by telling us we are not free to choose his ending...and then giving us the opportunity to do the exact opposite.I had moments where I was chuckling for a while, shaking my head at the absurdity of it all. Other times I burst out laughing.  Still other situations had me stopping to pause, genuinely questioning the implications of an event and how it related to my life."Ah, but the cons," you say, and rightly so.  Well, it does feel short.  Which is a concern when it's so easy to pick up cheaper games that last (a lot) longer.  I would very much recommend that you wait for a big sale for this game, particularly if your budget is constrained. To put it into perspective: I reckon (without giving away spoilers) that I've discovered more or less everything there is, and I don't have much time invested into the game.TL;DR: a recommended game, a brilliant story, but not a game that will keep you coming back for more hours later.

												Well, this is a new one. A First Person game where there is no shooting or puzzle solving. Mainly just making choices and exploring every area is what this game is all about. I enjoyed the comedic dialogue of the narrator and the strange endings that transpire depending on the different decisions you make. It had alot of confusing moments as rooms tend to change each time you come to a dead end. Even though everything seemed pretty random, alot of scripted dialogue was put into the game and possiblities were many but still I feel there should have been more. But I haven't made a game so I could not do any better than this. For the price I paid for it, it was nice and fun to play. I think I enjoy more the reaction I get from having my friends and family play it. I definitely enjoyed markiplier's commentary while he played the game. This is a fun game to experience once and then have your loved ones play as well.

Posted: January 26, 2016
												The Stanley Parable is a first person exploration game that makes the player think about the nature of choice in games while simultaneously managing to be a wildly entertaining, hilarious, and surprising experience.This game has a provocative and perpetual elusiveness that aches to break whatever system it’s applied to. The gameplay is quite simple, the graphics and environments are beautiful and the narrative is exquisite.The Stanley Parable is an incredible piece of self-satirical art that is unlike anything else I ever played and for that, I highly recommend it.

content:
Posted: July 18, 2016
												Brilliant in the most puzzling way.I bought this game on sale this summer, and I kind of put it off until now. I can't believe I waited that long, because this is one of the most fun games I have ever played.Although it can get a bit confusing, I find that is what makes it fun. If you get this game, though, I don't reccomend reading any guides until you've had your fill of tooling around. To me, at least, it makes the suprising game much more fun.ProsFirst off, the price! I think this should be worth much more.The narrator has a personality, and will indeed say different things depending on what you do throughout the game.There are SO many different endings, and I'm currently trying to get to them all. That being said, it is a time-well-spent undertaking since each one (most of them, at least) eludes to a bit more of the.. "Story"The story isn't actually a set one.The acheivements- take a look at them, real quick. The developers are genuises.Each of the endings gives you something different.Its freaking hilarious. That's the main thing.The creativity behind it all. Play the game to understand.Cons As I said, it can get somewhat confusing, especially for gamers looking for a straightforeward story.The story is pretty wavering. I still don't understand it fully.You get NO instructions at the beginning of the game, even though the controls are basic WASD and the mouse.At least 9/10, Please just give it a go. I've never laughed this hard at a video game before.

content:
Posted: March 21
												The Stanley Parable is not really a game, then again it is.Then again its not. Oh, look, now its pretending to be an alltogether different game.But all in all, it is just what it is: The Stanley ParableTheres nothing quite like this again on steam, so this is a dangerous affair for your dollars.Lets start by being mean to the game, as seldom people are.I honestly dont think that this is a game as good as the combined review-score puts it, and I honestly dont think its a game that has a large variety of people that would really >get< where the enjoyment lies.What rescues the stanley parable from being a weird outsider in the games playground is its very witty yet completely relateable approach of humor and its coherent way of telling (or not telling, or corrupting) a storyline. That I think is the one reason really everyone could give it a shot if its on sale.With regards to the mechanics: You can walk, you can interact or choose to not interact, that all. Its clean, it works, it has no bugs that I know of, and theres nothing that needs to be added to it, theres no missing part, everything makes sense. The Stanley Parable will be as challenging for you as your mind bends it to be. The biggest mechanic of this game are your own thoughts, and its very controversial to which degree it even could be called a game. This is not a casual buy like its advertised in my opinion, because the fun part happens outside of the screen.In some way you will get exactly of what you dont know you will get.Which absolutely seems like another plus, because buying this game now sounds like poetry.--------------------------------------------------------------------------So the only question that really counts and remains is: Do I recommend it for whatever it is, having played the whole game?It somewhat depends:- If you want it for the fun joyride you maybe have seen elsewhere, I dont recommend buying it except on sale. Not because its bad, but because I think 11,99 is too much for just the fun parts of the dialogue and the running around. You will have seen a fair bit of the game after playing 5 hours. (A more casual comparison to movies of course makes this worth it, but im comparing it to games, ultimately its your call.)- But, and the reason theres ultimately a thumbs up on this review: If you actually aspire to enter the whole brute force of the stanley parable, engage in its problems and think about just what the heck it all could mean. And If you want to explore in the empty office building of the entity named stanley and face the crisis of not knowing whats fake or real anymore, then its the time to stop reading this review right now, butcher your funds and start playing the game.For everyone that has the time and lust to wonder on his hands, this is what you would want to buy.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Introspective, hilarious, and dark, this is very much a game ABOUT games.  Above all, it's about the illusion of choice and how a game's narrative is constructed around that.  How does the Narrator control the story when the Player has agency to not follow his instructions?  Is a choice between two identical doors actually a choice?  Why can't these people just play my game the way I want them to?  The Stanley Parable is a satire, and an "arty" one at that.Be sure to play the demo, even if you plan on getting the game.  It's a completely seperate experience; nothing in it appears in the game proper.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2016
												A very short game... If you're a sheep.This game is very special, you can spend as much as 4 minutes and a bit or a few hours on this game. It's a kind of game that plays with the illusion of choice. What this game does is that it takes the 4th Wall, straps 20lbs of C4 to it, adds a sprinkle of thermite and lets it rip. But wait it ain't done with the 4th Wall yet oh no. It then fires 163613 jackhammers out of a cannon and a squirrel at it until that wall ceases to exist anymore. Donald Trump doesn't stand a chance against this game.You play as Stanley, or should I say "Employee No. 427". You sit in front of your 1980's era DOS interface CRT monitor and wait for instructions on which buttons to push on the keyboard. You are one of a plethora of generic employees who work for a corporation. What kind of corporation? I still have no clue. It kinda reminds me of the "1984" ad by Apple for their Macintosh.You are given instructions to follow by the narrator (a very amusing narrator I may add) of the game, but listening and conforming to those instructions is up to you, which also mean the consequences that follow for each instruction followed (or should I say not followed) are your responsibilty. It seems extremely linear at first, but once you realise you are the one controlling Stanley and not the narrator, the possibilities are endless.I aqcuired this game in the Summer Steam Sale for €2.39.Is it worth it? YesIs it up to you to decide if it is? Abso-****ing-lutelyMy rating? 7.5/10

content:
Posted: December 2, 2014
												"Please die."This game is the definition of "mind♥♥♥♥ing". Also, it is the first game I've ever seen that actually plays you, not in a funny 4th wall way like Portal, it actually go meta inside your head, messing with your feelings and driving you crazy.The Stanley Parable is a piece of art that unravels the true nature of game design and choice. The narrator does an excellent job at dragging you into Stanley's world, and you will actually feel your heart race even if you can only open doors and press buttons as gameplay action.There is only one caveat: this game will make you hate it, so keep calm and it's best advised not to  play it continuously in a single playthrough for extended periods of time (it is possible to "beat" the game and see all alternative endings in 6 hours of straight play, but that will make your mind weary).There is not much else to be said without spoiling the fun, it is already a classic and it is a must for any respectable gamer.

content:
Posted: June 19, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is a fascinating commentary on game design that simultaneously informs and entertains. You'll navigate the drab corridors of your mundane office constantly accompanied by the delightful narrator, instructing and reacting to your every decision. Your actions dynamically impact the games story and can lead you to any of 20+ endings available. Throughout the 5 hours I spent exploring the game, I was always excited to see whats around the next corner and explore every corner of a world that richly rewards its players for taking the path less traveled. Watching my friends play was an equally entertaining experience. Highly recommended with the games brevity in mind. 8/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 20, 2016
												8/10Not sure where to start with this review, but I will say this: this game messes with your mind! In terms of mechanics, this game is incredibly simple. It is a walking simulator set in a bland office building. But, in a game like this, mechanics and visuals really don't matter. For this little game, all you need to worry about is the satirical narrator and your choices.The Stanley Parable is an extremely peculiar but hilarious game. The humor is witty and sarcastic, and on occasion, can be rather dark. Also, forget the fourth wall in this one; it is practically nonexistent. Of course, we have the narrator to thank for that. He is extremely reactive to the player's behavior and will comment on the strangest things. (Get the Door 430 achievement; that's one of the best pieces of commentary in the game!) However, he also has some moments where he will either rail on the player in a fierce rant, or seriously guilt trip him/her in a somewhat dejected manner. These rapid changes in his dialogue can be a little disarming but give the narrator more depth as a character (if that is how you see him), thus having the potential to affect the way you play the game.Despite its fantastic humor, the game's primary focus is on its philosophical topics. Most of the time, those topics dance around in the background and are alluded to by the narrator. Where the really shine is in the "endings". Each one, no matter how quirky or funny, has some sort of message to convey. Some, as would be expected in this type of game, focus on the nature of choices, and whether or not they matter. Others may touch on subjects such as the meaning of life or one's perception of reality. These "endings" can be incredibly thought-provoking and deep; one in particular left me staring at my computer for about 15 minutes in contemplative shock. And, when I describe it as a shock, it's not hyperbole.Of course, what you get out of said endings is completely up to you. How will you interpret the endings and what the narrator has to say about them?So, to sum it all up, The Stanley Parable is an extremely clever and philosophical game that is sure to keep the player's attention all the way through(?). It is one of those special games that can give you both memorable laughs and the occasional existential crisis! Enjoy!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2015
												I'm not even sure what I played (or rather, am still in the process of playing).There is no right or wrong way to play this game. You cannot break this game. (Okay you CAN but that's somewhat hard to do.) The developers have thought of everything and have considered how you would react as a person, so they've added as much as they could. "What if I revisit this ending?" They considered that, too.This seems to be a game with an illusion of choice that's aware of that illusion. Or is it a game? Is it an interactive story? Can it really be a story? A walking sim with soul, really? And what of the narrator? Is he too, just an illusion? You're going to ask yourself a lot of questions. "What was that I just experienced? I need to do that again. But what if I just go through this door this time?"I kept clicking. I clicked when there was no obvious objective and discovered that was the right way. Or was that the wrong way? The irritation I caused the narrator delighted me, so this seemed like the right way to play to me. Of course until I splattered against the pavement, causing him much horror and sadness because "I must hate him" for some reason.What's the downside? Well, it's pretty easy to get the majority of endings in a short amount of time if you're that eager to keep going because you're just that interested. There is a hard ending that will take hours of dedicated game play, but even that becomes simple once you realize that yes, the developers have even thought about ways to obtain that ending. You'll end up resorting to playing just to take a screenshot of every easter egg just to say you found it. Not a horrible thing, but replayability-wise, the game doesn't sink a huge amount of time.That's about it, though. Otherwise, allow me to join those adding their voices to the glowing praise to The Stanley Parable.The break room is truly a work of art.Truly.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2016
												The Stanley Parable is a really great game when you have some time to spend on a fun and confusing game without a real purpose. It is a game basing on choices you make and the storyline is depending on that choices and changes with them as well. There are some outcomes that really are surprising and for some five bucks on sale it's really worth spending some hours in.Although if you are an achievment hunter like I am, I would say it has really easy ones, but they are really long and difficult to get if you do them the legitimate way. I did the commitment achievment and wasn't able to play anything else on a tuesday afternoon what really was an upsetting fact, but all in all I really enjoyed its basic gameplay and changing storyline. The narrator also makes this game what it is, so I can only recommend it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
												A wonderfully philosophical game that if paid the attention it deserves, will make you question just who Stanley really is, just who the narrator really is, and provide deep philosophical questions for you ponder, such as who is really in control of your reality, both as Stanley, and as whoever you are offline.It may not be who you think it is.There are no guns and no enemies to kill, no moon nazis or crafting diamond weapons on a crafting table with a hammer. Just philosophical deepness that is unsurpassed in any other game Ive played, but presented in wonderfully engaging way.This game is not for everyone. It is a very cerebral game at heart, that demands many more hours thinking about the story and how it plays out, than actually playing in it virtually.The voice acting of Kevan Brighting (Narrator) is also exceptional. It is above and beyond any video game voice work Ive ever heard. IMO, it is now the gold standard to compare other video game voice work to, hands down.I fully recommend this game to everyone.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												All I can say is, the game may look like Portal, and yes, it has a Portal feel to it, but don't go getting this game expecting Portal, because what you get is something completely different, but not a bad different.  Oh no-no-no.  This is a very good different.Basically the game is supposedly about making decisions...Which is true to some extent...But what it basically comes down to is you going down each different route one after another hunting each ending you can possibly find, whilst being narrated by a rather charming and witty narrator.  Who IS basically the reason you play the game anyway.Basically, if you enjoy intelligent humour and a video game that somewhat mocks other video games and film scenarios, then this is most definitely the game for you!  Whilst the game will sometimes hold your hand yo get you around, a lot of the time, you will find yourself wadering into a path you had never noticed the first time you went there before, even though it was there the whole time from the start.I would most definitely recommend this game!My rating: 88/100

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												There's so much to like about this game - the humour and writing, the not-so-subtle commentary on game design, the hidden endings - yet perhaps the greatest strength of "The Stanley Parable" is its underlying heart. The ability to empathize with the titular Stanley as he fails or succeeds in various degrees is what ties the whole package together. Plus, you can blow through all the content in five hours or so, making this is a quick investment with a ton of payoff.

content:
Posted: September 13, 2014
												I'm not even sure if we can call this a game, but if it IS a game, then it's one of the most ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ly hilarious games I've ever played. It just likes to f#ck arround with you, to the point that you notice it, this game breaks the fouth wall as much as Deadpool, and it's probably as funny.As usual, let's start with the bad stuff: First of all, the price. The game nearly has no real gameplay at all, it's rather a weird interactive story...And yet it's priced 12€? Good thing I picked it up on sale, for 8€. Some might argue that it was still too much, but it was worth it for that price. I do recommend to wait for a sale. And that's it. That's the only bad things the game has, lack of gameplay, and a pricetag too high. What does this game do well?You start as a guy named Stanley, a man who's job is to push buttons. Wow, he already works more than the government. Suddenly, though, he got the feeling of...What? That's where you get in. This is not Stanley's adventure. This is your adventure, because you're Stanley, I'm Stanley, he's Stanley, everyone is Stanley. Well, except the Government, those guys are Doctor Rektus Retardus♥♥♥♥♥♥Evacuation II. You do what you like. You want to advance the story? Do it. You want to go and do what you like? Do it. You want to stay in your room and not play? THERE'S EVEN AN ENDING FOR THAT.That's the game's selling point. The fact that, in a story this dumb, and short, there's an amazing number or endings, some of them reaching high levels of originality, or just being rather surprising, and unexpected. Sorry, I just can't bring myself to spoil any of them (I did spoil the one about not leaving the room...But that's the easiest ending of the game, dude. It takes like 2 seconds). If you want to trully experience this game, DO NOT LOOK FOR GUIDES, DO NOT LOOK FOR PLAYTHROUGHS, DO NOT LOOK TO LET'S PLAYS, ONLY LOOK AT THE TRAILER, AND THE DEMO. The story of the game is pretty much 8/10 of the game, the other 2 being the amazing narrator, and you will have infinitely more fun if you don't expect any of that crap to happen.The game is NOT worth 12€, like I said. But in a 50% sale, for 6€? At that price it would be a SHAMEFUL DISPLAY not to buy it. It's your choice, Stanley. Buy the game, and have fun, or look yourself in the first room for eternity.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												This is one of those games which deserves to be avoided at all costs until you can pick it up for yourself. Why? Because the best part of The Stanley Parable is seeing things unfold with no prior knowledge of what you're getting into. It's a hilarious game, that's for sure. But it can also be un-nerving to the point of being terrifying, amongst other things. That much I'll tell you, but I won't explain why. This is also a game which can be very fun with friends, I think. If you bring someone who has never even heard the words "Stanley," "Parable" and "The" in the same sentance and invite them to play this, their reactions are bound to be a sight to see. Just make sure you don't give them any hints or tips along the way.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												There's so much to like about this game - the humour and writing, the not-so-subtle commentary on game design, the hidden endings - yet perhaps the greatest strength of "The Stanley Parable" is its underlying heart. The ability to empathize with the titular Stanley as he fails or succeeds in various degrees is what ties the whole package together. Plus, you can blow through all the content in five hours or so, making this is a quick investment with a ton of payoff.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												Toy with the role of narrative in video games, the illusion of choice, and with just how narrow objectives in video games really are while breaking the fourth wall in The Stanley Parable. It's a game for people who spend forever wandering and poking about in games, for people who try to break games, and for people who defy games' orders just to see if they account for it.That said, it's not without its faults. The most savage review of The Stanley Parable I've seen was by its own head developer and he accurately points out that TSP is complicit in everything it skewers for lack of ability to think of better options. Let's not throw the word "genius" around willy-nilly. "Clever" is more accurate. TSP isn't going to start a revolution in storytelling in games, in addressing the problems inherent in providing choice within pre-constructed environments, or anything of that sort. It's just very clever. For me, it was enough "clever" to be happy with the purchase. Your mileage may vary.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												First, that game has hilarious narration.When looked at from one side, this game tells a short story about desperate worker class employant Stanley, who tries to escape the evil paths that were laid out before him. The narrator tries to help you on your path, and will respond to your choices with often unexpected and witty behaviour. Like, he will go angry at you when you refuse to leave the nice and cozy broom chamber, or get desperate when you try to ruin his narration by doing the opposite he tells you to. Then it also mocks you, either with giving you useless rewards or just offend you for even playing it. Worth a pretty good laugh and also an extremely likeable setting and characters.When looking at it from the other side, the game offers a deep philosophical discussion about choice, and how it influences our every lives on a daily basis. How it appears to be unique, to be freely available to have, almost a right to everyone. And how different choices in games are compared to choices in real life, and WHY we play the games we play. Why we emphasize on freedom of choice in games so much, even though there is no true freedom in a game ever to be had. But does this really differ from what we face in life, or is it just different approach to it?If you want to, this game can ask you a lot of question, and maybe also give you some answers. But don't expect them to come to you black in white, as the game is simply a discussion about choice, it doesn't try to answer it but moreso allow you to see it from different angles and then decide for yourself what you really want to believe.The game IS short, and it emphasizes multiple playthroughs and secret-searching to find the more than a dozen hidden endings and paths. Also it might be frustrating at times or even call you a fool, but it ever does it with a clear intention. It is NOT a game about progress, as you keep starting over and over again at the same place (which for sure is also an intention to reflect on vicious cycles we tend to run into).But it is a lovely game, and surely made a dent into the history of gaming (and into a few gamers brains), and I can recommend it to anyone willing to have patience with a game that revolves more around yourself and does have probably the most hilarious narration and unique humour a game had in the last few years.Also, if you decided to play it I suggest you watching this video AFTER you played it: 


YouTube™ Video: Errant Signal - The Stanley Parable 

			Views: 148,785		



DON'T watch it before you haven't played at least through the most obvious paths and endings, as it takes away a lot of the charm of trying to find out yourself what something means and also spoils quite a bit.OH, and PLAY THE DEMO before you play the game or decide to buy it. It offers completely different content but in the same way the original does and is like a chapter on it's own.Also there is the mod which the game is based upon, still freely available to download here if you aren't convinced yet: http://www.moddb.com/mods/the-stanley-parable8

content:
Posted: November 5, 2016
												Once upon a time, a player bought a game called "The Stanly Parable." He enjoyed controlling Stanley. In a game where the player explores an area, and plays the story however he wants to play it, there was much fun to be had, but the best fun of all was♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off the game's narrator, who in turn trolled the player when he tried to earn an achievement by clicking on door 430 five times. Ah yes, poor ol' Stanley, who is at the mercy of two evil forces constantly fighting against each other; the player and the Narrator. But enough about, that. What did the player do when he reviewed the game?One day, the player decided to make a review for the game. He suddenly heard a voice in his head, telling him "This game sucks! Click on the thumbs down!" But the player decided not to listen to this voice, and instead clicked the thumbs up. Then the voice said "Do you not realize who I am?! This is the voice of a snobby hipster gamer who complains about every single popular game, and any other game he chooses not to like just to look cool! You can't just defy me like that! Do you not know that people like me consist of the 2,176+ people that give this game a bad rating just cuz?! We will hunt you down! I'm one of those people you don't want to mess with, chump. I'm one of those half-witted ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ who do cool stuff like hating on Red Dead Redemption and saying that Gun is a better game, even though it's got potato graphics, a much smaller world to explore, and just less content in general. This game isn't even a game! It sucks!"But the player decided not to listen to this trivial whiner, and instead praised the game for what it truly was: an exploration game that allows you to test outcomes. He didn't expect it to be something it wasn't meant to be, like a shooter. He praised it for what it was as a game. And everyone lived happily ever after, unlike people who behave like this guy.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 23, 2015
												A captivating adventure into the assumptions of game design itself. If you are a next-level game enthusiast, as in; you enjoy the discussion of what games are, can do, mean, etc just as much and maybe more than playing through games themselves; this is for you. Technically, The Stanley Parable is less of a traditional game and more of a choose-your-own-adventure… Or is it? Or are all games really just about toying out the desired/possible outcomes? These are the conversations the Stanley Parable evokes and it is less played and more unlocked like a puzzle. I’d actually prefer you to not read or watch any footage of the game if you can help it; for much of the game’s charm is in your brain’s reaction as you make decisions. Much of that tension is lost if the events of the game are spoiled, or almost as badly, if another person holds the responsibility of making choices instead of you.I’ve been far too vague, I know. You, Stanley, wander about a seemingly innocuous office environment listening (or not) to a narrator. The “game” is about making choices and unlocking the outcomes the designers have made for you. Some of these outcomes are unlocked obviously, some require a bit of ingenuity and others literally require hours of dedication. My suggestion is to dig into this game chillaxed out with your own preferred inebriation (drugs are bad kids, mmkay?) and find as much out for yourself as you can. After a few hours then start googling around, because the things you find yourself will have more value to you than the outrageous stuff you missed. If any of this nerdy♥♥♥♥♥♥sounds interesting to you, but it without hesitation. The Stanley Parable will spruce up the scholarliness of your Steam library like a PhD hanging on a wall next to a bookshelf.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												Very few games have impressed me the way "The Stanley Parable" did. I was stunned to see I only played for 2.7 hours when writing this, because it feels like I spend a lifetime in this game, walking through the ever shifting and changing story, finding new paths with every turn.The Stanley Parable is about choosing or not choosing, following or disregarding the path laid out in front of you, and about one of the freaking best narrations in videogame history. And quite a few of the best jokes; I think the games that made me laugh the most were Portal 2 and The Stanley Parable. But not only laughter, also deep confusion, mindbending twists and moments of sadness are part of your way through the hallways.On a whole whether you should buy this game depends on what you want from a game: If you want hours upon hours of entertainment, this will not satisfy you. But if you value an interesting experience, even for a few bucks, this is definetily your thing! Plus, the time you actually spend with the game is quite a bit longer, considering how much you will have to ponder what actually happened before your eyes.Also: Did you get the "Broom closet ending"? The "Broom closet ending" was my favourite!

content:
Posted: January 9, 2015
												My first run through, I followed the narrator's advice the whole way through, and got that ending. It wasn't anything special, so I figured all endings were like that. Uninstalled the game that night. Reinstalled it several months later, thinking there was some stuff I was missing.Of course there was. Some of the fun in the game is in ignoring the Narrator and doing whatever you want to do. I have never had a game make me laugh so hard at the consequences of staying in a bloody janitor's closet several times throughout the game. There are many endings, and part of the fun is finding them all. Be adventurous, disregard the narrator, jump out seemingly innocuous windows - you are Stanley. Choose your path.

content:
Posted: January 14, 2015
												This has got to be one of my favourite PC games!! Everything from the fresh concept to the amazing narrative voice work make this a very enjoyable experience I think everyone should enjoy.Game Showcase-


YouTube™ Video: (Game Showcase)The Stanley Parable- Messing with the Narrator 

			Views: 10		

			In today's Game Showcase we take a look at The Stanley Parable. A game in which the narrator is trying to tell you a story, except you don't always half to do what the narrator says.		

      -------Summary at the bottom-------GameplayThe gameplay feels fresh and its very enjoyable. The narrator tells you what to do and you follow his directions, or try to change the story by taking a different route. The narrator adapts to what you do through his dialouge as well as makes snarky hilarious comments towards you for not following him in the beginning. The more you change the narration the more he becomes frustrated and the more its noticable in the dialouge. No matter what you do, it seems the deveopers were planning on you being able to do that. In one instance you can glitch through a window to where you thought you had broke the game and exited the level, but nope. The narrator picks right up telling you "I bet you thought you could get out of here" "is this what you really want? is to leave?". The game is however a little short but there are so many different endings some more complicated than others and some very hard to produce. This can keep you playing for long after, trying to see all the different endings and experience all the hilarious and clever lines the narrator has.GraphicsThe graphics are average, but nothing to special. Its built on the Source Game Engine so think other source games such as half life 2, counter strike, etc.. Levels are well designed and their are lots of different areas to explore and check out, but first you must figure out how to get to them :).AudioThe audio in this game is by far the best part. The narrator is hilarious and clever and will keep you smiling and laughing while you try to trip him up. The actor chosen to voice the narrator was a perfect pick in my opinion. His voice stuck in my head for days after. SummaryThe stanley parable filled my need for a fresh game. The clever game design allows for so many different endings that will keep it feeling enjoyable as you listen to the hilarious narrator try to keep up with you as you try to trip him up. If your looking for something that feels a little fresh and will give you a good laugh then this will satisfy that.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Short Version:THIS GAME MAKES BIOSHOCK INFINITE LOOK LIKE BAD FANFICTION. F**KING PLAY THIS GAME.Long Version:The Stanley Parable is a game about possibilities. Every time you restart the game, you enter a parallel universe where everything is (almost) the same except for which actions the player takes, among a few other random variables (I.E. whether the floor is covered in papers). The game's sole purpose is to examine the very nature of storytelling in video games, pointing out just how "fake" the illusion of choice is, and laughing at the player for thinking they have some semblance of control over each predefined story branch.It's literally impossible to go into further detail without spoiling something about the game. There's no real gameplay to spoil - hell, the player can't even jump. The only thing you can do is walk around, push buttons, and choose whether to go left or right based on the narrator's dialogue. Everything else that matters about this game is the ways in which the game sets up certain expectations and then subverts the hell out of them in some spectacularily ballsy ways. I'm honestly amazed that there isn't an ending where the game crashes to desktop.I don't care who you are or what you're interested in. All I know is that if you call yourself a gamer, you need to play this game. For the love of whatever-your-diety-of-choice-is, just play this game. You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: December 3, 2013
												Similar Games:It’s fairly unique, although certain moments are reminiscent of Antichamber.The Good:The narrator’s voice acting is excellent; it’s easy to forget that it’s someone reading lines.Having an invisible narrator delivering an awesome performance has two distinct benefits to the overall game: 1) enabling the player to imagine their own version of the antagonist and 2) sidestepping having to model a visual representation that would live up to the player’s expectations. A clever move from a game design standpoint, whether intentional or not.Some seriously creepy/unexpected moments, even having played the mod version. One scene left me literally staring at the screen in disbelief.Triggered animations are perfectly timed – there are no “glitch” moments because you made it to an area before the game thought you would, etc.The game includes a “Disable Achievements” option! (Ed. note: this may have swayed my entire opinion of the game)The text on in-game computer screens balances between tongue-in-cheek parodies of corporate jargon and self-aware references to the gaming industry. Somehow, neither of these manage to break the immersion.The multiple “endings” vary immensely, and manage to pull the curtain back in satisfyingly different ways each time.The Bad:The “games are not art” crowd might dislike this game due to sticking with their party platform; they are wrong.Players who try to speed-run through the game will miss out on the excellent voice acting, and may actually cut off the narrator mid-phrase. This is more of a critique against speed-runners than the game.The loading screens kinda (barely) give away the concept of the game’s “ending.”The Writing:This is one of the most well-written games I have ever played. I was a huge fan of The Stanley Parable when it was “only” a HL2 mod, and the full game hits the same marks and then some.The game has a “Choose Your Own Adventure” feel, and does a great job of seamlessly adapting to virtually any action the player makes.The entire game manages to convey a sense of underlying dread, regardless of the choices you make – even the “happy” outcomes are never portrayed as being 100% certain.Did I make time to complete it:Many times, although (spoiler alert) that’s kinda “the point.”Recommended Purchase Price:If you’re a fan of unconventional games, philosophy, psychology, existentialism, spiritual ennui, fatalism, causality and/or intellectually challenging games that make you think about anything whatsoever, this is a must-buy. $11.99 is a STEAL.Reviewer:Mudlabhttp://www.gamersglance.com

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												You're paying for a 'sudden realization', not a game. A narrative and satire, not a game (but still a decent narrative. I enjoyed the narration for what it's worth. Kinda funny). Don't fall for the cryptic desciptions on steam thinking there's a mystery to solve that nobody wants to give away like I did. The concept is pretty clever and it has it's moments but The Stanley Parable is still overpriced for what it offers in my opinion. I didn't exactly know what I was paying for when I bought it, but I heard/read it was somthing amazing and this and that. I'm not usually swayed by those types of reviews but this one had some type of psycological lure to it I couldnt resist. The  demo didn't clarify the game for me but made me more curious, so I guess it served it's purpose (lol).... When I actually bought it I expected a challenge of some sort, and because I don't like to be spoiled I was reluctant to read some reviews labled 'spoiler' or watch many videos. When I realized the 'point' of the stanley parable was the whole spoiler nobody wants to give away I stopped playing, feeling the same way alot of other reviwers did. . I felt like I could have watched someone play it for free and recieve the message just fine.Moral of the story: Know what you're paying for. Really make sure you know what you're paying for...

												A rather clever game, though people saying it's brilliant or genius are blowing it out of proportion. Got it on sale for $3 and that's about what it's worth. I have about 7 hours on file but a couple of those are from letting friends play it, but I finished just about every ending in about 2 1/2 hours, and there is zero replay value once you've completed all the multiple endings. number of helpful: 71 of 138 people (51%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2014
												I picked this up on sale for $5.99, because I've heard good things and thought "Only six bucks, why not?". If I had paid the full price for this game ($14.99 as of right now), I'm sure I would have felt cheated and ripped off.Let me elaborate. The Stanley Parable is not a terrible experience. I say "experience" rather than "game" for reasons I will explain momentarily. The Stanley Parable makes some decent points about video games and video game narratives. There was some good work put into the project, and it does succeed in delivering its message.Here's the issue: There is nothing in The Stanley Parable that really justifies purchasing it. The entire lesson that it teaches (the very reason it exists is because the developers wanted to teach this lesson), could have been conveyed just as well (if not better) in a short video or a magazine article. You would gain just as much benefit from watching a walkthrough of The Stanley Parable as you would from actually playing it. The gameplay in The Stanley Parable is minimal. There are no items to collect, no secret doors to open, no objectives to complete, nothing to do besides listen to a voice lecture you. It actually makes matters worse that The Stanley Parable is well aware of how basic its gameplay is, and simply hangs a lampshade on the issue.As far as being a philosophical message about video games (and, in some ways, life itself), The Stanley Parable is great. As far as being a video game, The Stanley Parable is awful. It seems like The Stanley Parable is getting hailed as a form of highly intellectual entertainment that some people simply won't understand. The general consensus (whether the developers intended this or not) seems to be that if you don't like The Stanley Parable, it's because you simply didn't grasp its revolutionary and intelligent message. This is not true. The message, while interesting, is not complicated or highly intellectual at all. And if you didn't like The Stanley Parable, it's probably because you were disappointed with its basic gameplay and low amount of content.I don't recommend purchasing The Stanley Parable for full price. It might be worth picking up if you can snag it while it's on sale, but frankly, you might at well watch one of the many walkthroughs on YouTube. You'll get the same value without spending a dime.

												Stanley, Stanley, Stanley, Stanley, Stanley, Stanley, Stanley, Stanley.Welcome to the game where the narrator gets your name wrong, always! Unless your name is Stanley, which sadly is a rare thing these days. You play as yourself, tapping buttons on a keyboard whenever a computer tells you to, for the length the computer tells you to.Welcome to the game where the narrator never actually addresses you! Unless you are indeed a phantasmorgial being, which sadly is a rare thing these days. You play as yourself, a ghost, haunting the narrator for his sins against a man named Stanley.Welcome to the game where you can play other games in it! Unless in fact you have those games, which sadly is a rare thing these days. You play as [REDACTED], a player of a game, playing games. Enticing.Welcome to the game where you are the one being played.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Play this game now. seriously!!. The Stanley Parable is unlike any other game I`v seen before mostly because it never gets old. there are many choices you face in the game for example I don`t want to spoil to much but in the beginning of the game you will face two doors depending on which you choose will lead you down a another path. But what really amazes me is that the game gives you the freedom to make the choices you want to choose, While other games usually have an invisible barrier of somekind blocking your path from certain hallways, in the Stanley Parable you are aloud to walk down those hallways. For example I was playing the game for about the third or second time looking for a differnt ending. I passed the door towards the end of the hall I always past. But then the idea ran through my head what if I could open it. I never tried it before because in most other games I had played I would try to open doors and nothing would happen. But to my suprise the door opened. In I stepped a broom closet. I don`t want to give away to much but the narrator after that told many jokes for example< "there`s nother in there" and "oh I suppose next time you see your friends your going to ask them if they ever got the broom closet anding in the Stanley Parable". To wrap it all up, this game is amazing I think everyone should enjoy the experience of the game that feels like it never ends.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
												You play the role of Stanley, the titular protaganist that seems satisfied with his extremely boring life. But "play" here is more of term for acting out a part than engaging in a game. The Stanley Parable is barely even a game, but instead an interactive fiction that entices you to go down the same doors again and again in the hope that you will see all of the games many endings. There's nothing to collect, no one to kill, and you can't even jump. You just turn down halls and go down doors. On papar, this may sound boring, but the way it's done is the charm of the game. The Narrator is reminiscent of Portal's Glados: you're never quite sure if he's your friend, your enemy, or your master. 40% of the games enjoyability is because of him and the voice actor who plays him. The rest of the enjoyment is deciding what path to go on or just finding new ones. Each of them means something. WHether it's poking fun at mainstream gaming tropes or telling you a sad story that may actually reflect your life, you'll genuinely want to see everything this deceptively complex "game" has to offer.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
												So... the Stanley Parable. Trying not to be repetitive. Trying really hard not to be repetitive and overtly hip. It's a game that plays itself in more sense than one. At the same time, being the thing it is, it lets you in deeply, makes you have a very good look on what's going on. If it wasn't meant for you, you will stop playing it after 20 minutes at most. If it was meant for you you will stop playing it after two hours at most but what you will play in those two hours will not be un-played for a while.Bottom line, I think I love it. This computer screen makes me say so, anyway. But I kinda want to hate it, to love it even more.And that, I hope, sums up how I played it. You should give it a go.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												To be utterly and completely honest and sincere, this game is hilarious, thought-provoking, mind-boggling, and revelation-enducing. The experience is one where you'd have to see it for yourself to experience the true wonder; where you yourself would form your own thoughts about the game whilst playing it. You can't get the full experience just by watching a YouTube commentary. Hands down, this game was an incredible ride and I've been looking forward to it ever since the release of the original Half-Life 2 Mod. BUT, once it's over, the magic is kind of gone. I know you're discovering new stuff every minute and when you least expect it, the game takes another turn to a road you haven't been down before, but despite the slogan, there really is an end. While there's no true definite ending for the Stanley Parable (that's for you to decide), the end of the content comes rather quickly. My suggestion is to not binge this game, or else you'd be getting closer to having nothing left. Unless there's an update, I cannot truly experience the same things in the same ways I did the first time. My verdict: Buy it and play it. However, buy it whenever this game is on sale. That is all.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												This game questions every convention and stereotype of video game story-telling; and does so with an incredible sense of humour. Stanley's story plays out however you want it to play out, and no matter where you decide to lead him, the journey is hilarious and immersive. In fact, 'The Stanley Parable' to me is more immersive than expansive RPGs such as Skyrim or Fallout.If you're looking for a laugh, something unusual, or to question the plot of every game you've ever played, give 'The Stanley Parable' (my 2013 game of the year) a try. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												The Stanley Parable transcends the concept of a traditional game.  There are many endings, yet there is no real ending at all.  You will make choices, yet you will have no real choice at all.  Sound confusing?  Well it should.  The Stanley Parable will make you question reality, the notion of free will, and the meaning of life itself through its witty, cynical sense of humor.  The narration is top-notch, keeping you entertained throughout this unpredictable journey.  There is never a dull moment.  You will always be discovering new things, adding to the replayability factor of the game. This is not a game for everybody.  You will likely either love it or absolutely hate it.  I would suggest trying out the demo.  If you enjoy that, consider purchasing the full version.  If not, this probably isn't the game for you.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2013
												You're looking for a recommendation.Will you find it?You're looking for an awesome game.Will this be it?You're looking for answers, yet question if this is truely the recommendation for that.Would I be here, now, typing away at something with a positive recommendation if it were not a good game?Is it possible that I, the typist, the recommender, the guidance through an unforseen title, am not the one in control of this recommendation?Would it be entirely possible that by the act of reading this recommendation you are now subjectively reconsidering your purchase?What is the point of this game anyways? What is the point of considering such a question?Is this game amazing, or is it lacking perfection?This. This is the only possible way I can and can not recommend The Stanley Parable.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												Okay look, the game is different. It is very different from anything you have played really. What one finds in a game like this is not a single story. There is no right way to play this game. On your first playthrough you will really discover the type of person you are. The guy who does as he is told or the one who does not. However, These are all things that you have briefly read by others about the game. This part is for you. I say this with love my brothers and sisters. If you get this game and bash it, then you are just as myopic and misanthropic as the narrator makes stanely out to be. This is a great physcological game. You need to challenge yourself to defy the narrator and thats where the beauty comes in. The narrator, is not your average narrator. He is trying to work with you in one story, against you in another, and for the both of you in others. You will make him angry, you will make him happy, you will make him sad. The true beauty in this game is the dynamic range of emotions the narrator will expirence when you defy him. Imagine being the swellest guy in the world and you just want to help others. You have to help a man that the unthinkable happened to and he cant figure out why and you are the only one guiding him. Would you blame him or trust him? Thats for you to decide. Will the narrator cry with joy or repent with mallice thats for you to decide and for you to relate to. All in all the atmosphere is great, it most certainly is the most unique game I have played. Lastly, If you listen to this game not as a gamer not as a story hunter but rather with your heart, open mind, and your life expirences you find yourself feeling a wide range of emotions that compel you to do one thing on one play through and another on the other. This game really finds who you, who us, who we, the stanely's are. I do beleive the original asking price is a bit steep but scoop this gem while it is on sale and you will never regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
												The Stanley Parable is an interesting game. If I told you why it was interesting that would ruin the fun. This is a game about discovery, though the story is confined. This is a game about choices, though your choices will not matter. This is a game with a rich story that you will probably not even get on the first playthrough.This game is a tragedy, a comedy, and a drama all at once.This is game is the story of a man named Stanley. And this parable is one to be listened to.This game is very genre-breaking, and ground-breaking, and just "breaking" in general. It defies commonality and shows us how games can cause us to ponder the bigger questions by posing them in a simple, easy to understand way. There are many great things critics could say about this game, but I will say none of those. I'll just reccomend it, wholeheartedly.

												Where do I begin.I haven't read any other reviews so I'm sorry if this sounds like a copy and paste of someone else. I just wanted to throw in my two cents.This game is amazing. If you are even slightly on the fense about this game, buy it. It -is- one of those "hush hush" games where people dont like talking about it because it could "spoil" whats fun. Honeslty, when i tell my friends to play it, they ask "why?" its really hard to tell them. Do I spoil the main aspect of it? do I spoil how many times you can... well... but do I??? things that wont spoil anything: well, you play a guy and you listen to a different guy talk the entire time, but you get that if you just watch the trailer for the game, its the same opening you get when you play the game. What I can say though, for sure, is just that its so imaginative and creative. You can tell the makers really had fun with this game. It tries to take you through several emotions and a lot of times they really did hit me. I felt sad, happy, confused, a little scared, it all just comes together to make me really enjoy the time i spent playing this game. I told my friends to get it and they thanked me for the experience.I give this game, a Go Buy It out of 10

												What can I say to recommend this game? I....I think I'm in love. I never thought one of my favorite games would have such minimal gameplay. This game is absolutely pointless and that's one of the many reasons why it's so wonderful. Everything about the execution of this game is just brilliant. Just everything, from the humor, to the well-placed voice cues, to the sometimes ridiculous, sometimes sinister narrator. The team that made this game deserve every penny they made from it, and many, many more pennies to come. This is genuinely worth your time and money. Go buy it now.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
												Play this game now. seriously!!. The Stanley Parable is unlike any other game I`v seen before mostly because it never gets old. there are many choices you face in the game for example I don`t want to spoil to much but in the beginning of the game you will face two doors depending on which you choose will lead you down a another path. But what really amazes me is that the game gives you the freedom to make the choices you want to choose, While other games usually have an invisible barrier of somekind blocking your path from certain hallways, in the Stanley Parable you are aloud to walk down those hallways. For example I was playing the game for about the third or second time looking for a differnt ending. I passed the door towards the end of the hall I always past. But then the idea ran through my head what if I could open it. I never tried it before because in most other games I had played I would try to open doors and nothing would happen. But to my suprise the door opened. In I stepped a broom closet. I don`t want to give away to much but the narrator after that told many jokes for example< "there`s nother in there" and "oh I suppose next time you see your friends your going to ask them if they ever got the broom closet anding in the Stanley Parable". To wrap it all up, this game is amazing I think everyone should enjoy the experience of the game that feels like it never ends.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2014
												Easily my favourite game of 2013. I'd heard about the mod for years, but never got around to giving it a go, and I'm kind of glad I didn't, because it might have lessened the impact this game had on me. I'm also glad that I did very little research into the game or what it was about. It was the demo that got me. I'd honestly thought I'd never be surprised by a game again, especially not one based on a mod that had been sitting around for years. I hope games like this inspire more developers to ignore established genres, stop trying to make the next AAA franchise, and try something new. Gaming should always be about innovation and trying to create a unique experience with each title, instead of just sticking to established formulae.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												The Stanley Parable isn't a game. It's an experiment in the thought process of giving a player the illusion of choice; how games make people believe that they actually have freedom of choice and what they do actually affects the game when in reality, everything is pre-destined no matter what. If I were to say anymore, it would simply spoil the "game".The Stanley Parable is a must-play title that deserves all of the atention it gets. It's a mind-puzzler that really makes you laugh and think about what games actually let you do. Everyone deserves to "play" this title.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This is the story of a man named Stanley. Stanley has an adventure dictated by his good friend, the Narrator, a charming Brit with a dry sense of humour and a fondness of shattering the fourth wall. Stanley has free reign to as he desires. He may disobey the Narrator if he so chooses. Consequences may or may not apply. The Narrator may throw Stanley to the wolves, or save him via Deus Ex Machina. Literally anything could happen. Stanley could be subject to a huge mind control experiment, or may find himself at odds with the Stanley Parable Adventure Line, or may even visit a museum dedicated to the Stanley Parable, built on the ashes of the fourth wall. A thoughtful parody on the nature of choice, and whether it exists in video games, the Stanley Parable quickly and voilently alternates between goofy, charming endings, and endings that will give you nightmares for weeks to come. The Stanley Parable offers something for everyone.

So as you're trying to choose between this and another game, just remember that you don't have true choice in most other games. content:
Posted: October 24, 2013
												This game is unbelievably good.  It dwells at the limit of what could be called a "game," playing with the idea of "choice" in video games by smashing the 4th wall and establishing a video game as an allegory for free will, all under the watchful, winking eye of a hilariously deadpan narrator.  It stomps staid video game tropes willy-nilly and tries its damndest to guide you through an adventure of epic proportions.  But the real adventure is found straying from the predetermined path.  Or are you really straying?  What is the adventure?  Play it and find out.  P.S. check the broom closet every time.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												Very entertaining game. Worth a purchase if it's on sale in my opinion. It doesn't last long, but on the other hand it does last long. It's really all about how you play it, or want to play it. Then you start asking yourself... is this really even a game... or is it... my life? I now think this game is my life. As I'm typing this I can't tell if I'm pretending to be Stanley (myself) typing away at a keyboard imitating myself in real life or if I'm myself (Stanley) and writing a review of a game about my life. I don't want to type this review of my life anymore. It's confusing me. Is this what I do for a living? I can't remember. Oh, wait, yes I can! That is what I do! I write reviews of my life for a living. I must be tired today for forgetting such simple facts. Well, it was enjoyable playing this game while it lasted but I want to go back to my apartment and my loving wife.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												This game has a very unique sense of humor that is a blend of both American and British humor.  In this game you play as Stanley, a grossly typical office worker, who's job is to push buttons.  When Stanley finds that one day, all of his coworkers are gone, it is up to the player to investigate just what's going on.There are many endings that provide an entertaining conclusion to Stanley's incredibly repeatable story.  If you do not wish to simply look up the endings, you are entitled to hours of fun, searching for all the endings.The game is very short, but the it loves to reset itself once you run into one of the many comical roadblocks that you'll eventually find.  The omniscient narrator provides interesting commentary, as well as playing the role of a partner of sorts.  He'll comment on your decisions, (or lack thereof, in some cases) and will also give you certain ideas as to what comes next.The game is immensly enjoyable, but has one flaw: this is simply an hd re-release.  Instead of paying fifteen dollars, you can quite easily install the mod as long as you own half-life 2.  This version features nothing in terms of additions, save for the narrator.  You are essentially paying fifteen dollars for some mp3 files.  While he does add some flavor to the game, he can be rather arbitrary at times, and ruin one's immersion.  On a side note, some of the achievements are quite confusing and annoying, where others are hilarous to take part in.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2013
												The humorous and intriguing demo and various 'trailers' is definitely what sold me on this game. Having really no idea what to expect as far as gameplay, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the actual game is very similar to others that I enjoy.Metaphorically, the 'normal' child of HalfLife2 to its crazier siblings Portal & Antichamber, TSP is not as straight forward as it seems in the screenshots. In fact... forward might not be the proper word at all. Perhaps, sideways is better. TSP is a game of replay. Not very long in any one 'game'. But you will be guaranteed to play for hours and hours exploring all the options. And of course, you will enjoy every moment figuring it out. A puzzle game with little rewards and high satisfaction. Keep Stanley alive... and find some company for him, will ya?Framed by a great voice over, at once humorous and maddening, The game keeps you smiling even as it frustrates. And don't worry. I'm sure you can 'finish' the game.... but can you finish it?Obligatory scoring: Visuals: Simple, nothing spectacular, but sets the proper mood and environment. No glitches found. Minimal interactivity. Small texture set, fitting the relatively 'small' game. 7/10Audio: Content - 10... Great writing in this game. No real soundtrack to speak of.Gameplay - well its really simple in essence.... so scoring here would be misleading. -2 for no jumping :POverall enjoyment - 9/10.Not a long experience... but a thoroughly enjoyable one!

content:
Posted: March 21, 2016
												The Stanley Parable is a good video game. It's not very long, it doesn't require too much dexterity, and if you wanted to be reductive, you could call it a "Walking Simulator."But it's fun. It made me laugh, it made me giggle, and there was one part that made me feel genuinely like a bad person. There are also tons of secrets to find, which on some level, is kind of the whole point of the game, really. I actually ended up using a guide to find the last two or so I'd missed, and I don't regret it in the slightest. I'm actually a little surprised it only took four hours, because to be honest, it felt like I played this game all afternoon and well in to the evening, and I mean that in the best way possible. It's a good game to get lost in.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
												It provides an experience no medium other than a video game could. The Stanely Parable couldn't be a film, a book or a radio drama because no matter how good they are, they lack two key things - participation, and the ability to restart. Only in games does restarting change anything. In The Stanely Parable, it has the potential to change everything, and keep changing everything, right up to the point where you realise that you are in fact changing nothing. This constant feeling of 'it's about this...wait...actually it's about that' is what this game centres around. You will feel trapped, liberated, antagonistic, companiable, satisfaction, guilt, unease and serenity, sometimes all within the same playthrough. It's not something that demands anything technical of you, but it is a game. It's quintessentially a game, and in a medium that often seems envious of film, The Stanely Parable uses the format to deliver something unique, and is one of my favourite experiences in a very long time.

content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Just.........The lights are so beautiful, and my girlfriend has now forgiven me for my difficulty in emotional connection and committment. I am now at her door at 3am, i still have the spare key and in my hands is her favorite coffee and pastry. She will be so happy, that such simple gestures of affection i have been too timid to express previously are now a sign of my transformation into the person she always knew was hiding behind the cold and distant mask. I open the door, my heart is racing and i am in a cold sweat, but i battle and defeat my fears and feel a warmth of excitement. As i reach for the light, i think otherwise, place the goods on the table and sneak into the bedroom of the small 2 room apartment. I slowly reach for the bed in the darkness, put my hand under the covers and lightly squeeze her warm thigh, I whisper to her that i will never forsake the feelings i have for her, and i nibble her ear like she always loved..... WTF THIS TASTES LIKE CHALK, OMG SHES A ♥♥♥♥ING WOT............................ :( of course i dont have a girlfriend, still in my fearful ways. Well, maybe some day :o

Never in a game I have done nothing at all so often just for the hope of squeezing another witty remark out of the game. A nice little, but way too short of a game. I just would have loved to have a gazillion more turns to go through...
