number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												Stanley this, Stanley that. Stanley this, Stanley that. Stanley this, Stanley that. When I set down to play this game, I didn't expect it to be the other way around. From the moment the reins of control, or the illusion of it, are handed to you, the masterpiece known as The Stanley Parable spins into motion. I've always tested video games, going back to where I started, finding a way out of maps, and generally screwing with whatever the devs have come up.But The Stanley Parable stood ready to accept what I had coming for it. When I was able to take my first tentative steps into this game that I knew almost nothing about, my first choice in this game about choices was to stay put where I started, and the results impressed both me and the rest of my house at 2 AM as I found myself unable to breathe for the next 30 seconds. Remember how I said that this game is about choice? Well it is, and isn't. There is no choice system like a Bethesda game, instead the choice system can be more or less described in the first evident fork in the road you encounter in this maze of a game. Two open doors in front of you, with a narrator expecting you to go through one of them. From there all hell can break loose, resulting in one of my favorite games of all time. -Gameplay: Walking Simulator 2013 best Simulator. 5/5-World: The omnipresent narrator is a delight to indulge and anger and having the game itself react and warp around you is an unparalleled experience. 5/5-Story: What story? Ah, that story. The writing and subtle jokes and references may fly over most people, but for those who understand then The Stanley Parable will prove to have one of the greatest story-shaped holes in existance. 5/55/5 no really buy this game what is this game even about I am on fire please send help.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2015
PROS:+ simple & fun gameplay+ hilarious narrative+ interesting level design+ original game concept+ multiple endings (& semi-endings)CONS:- a bit short (base) game time- some achievements are extremely hard to get- limited action possibility (although it probably would not work otherwise)Comment:The Stanley Parable is one of those games that stands out, a game that you will remember. It is a first person narrated interactive adventure and it is LOADS of fun. I heard about how good it is from various sources but I hesitated towards buying it as I thought it would not be my kind of game. But it is ... it is my kind of game ... and most probably it is your kind of game too. Because it is very well scripted, nicely exectued and even makes you think about the mechanics of modern games. About how the achievements have no real meaning and about video game cliches. When talking about achievements I have to mention that this game is merciless to achievement hunters. Especially 3 achievements require either file editing, computer time tuning or just plain luck. Base game took me about 6 hours, the extra 25 are for one achievement. Overall this game was well worth the price and while being a bit limited in what you can do it still offers a different view on video games. I recommend it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
												Gameplay: The Stanley Parable constantly subverts many of the tropes established by AAA video-games, to mention them here would be to spoil their inclusion, all I will say is this; the game is marevellously deconstructs the very essence of contemporary video-game design and the way in which many players are lured in by cheap tricks and superficial incentives. Fortunately this is not done in a pretenious or off-puting way, rather with subtlety and entertaining enthusiasm.Story: The plot is absolutely incredible, and best experienced with no prior knowledge.Graphics: Influences from many Source games like Portal 2 and Half Life 2 are clear, although the game has a rather unique visual style of its own. The environments are nicely detailed, lighting is top notch and there are several instances of visual trickery on an M.C. Esher level.Re-playability: There are over a dozen unique endings and many small details to find throughout the intricately designed level(s).

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 21, 2013
												Odd doesn't even begin to describe such an experience. If you haven't played the Stanley Parable yet but you are absolutely certain you're getting it, I would reccommend you stop reading this "review" at once, as I have a feeling this may somewhat ruin the experience I previously mentioned earlier for you. I would want anyone whom begins to play this game to have absolutely no knowledge of what lies within it.Now- the only people that should be reading this are those whom are uncertain of whether or not they're getting this and the rebels who'll do as they damn well please.If you try and look up what other people think about this game, I find they just state a bunch of contrasting hypocritical statements about it to try and endorse the strange factor and make you want to buy the game even more- but rather than waste your time and do that I'm just going to explain how I feel about it and what it is, so hopefully you walk away with some knowledge, despite being warned in advanced about how it may ruin the initial experience upon purchase. I mentioned that the experience you get from playing this game was odd- I do not want you to think that I mean that in a negative respect. It is strange, but in a good way- not exactly the sort of whacky forced strange people have become acustomed too these days, but a somewhat intellectual twine ontop of a seemingly endless amount of optional storylines. You play as Stanley, an officer worker and with the help of the narrator you make your way through the short story and get to the ending- seems simple, yes? The cliche is that there's the freedom to disobey whatever it is the narrator says so that you can potentially mess up the entire story and branch off from it. The substory branches are surprisingly long which is why I almost guarantee you'll play through this game more than once, just in a different way- you'll be so curious that you'll want to know what happens if you did A instead of B and vice versa. The games humour overall appeals to me immensely. The narrators voice and tone fits perfectly with the silent little character that is Stanley. Small little things such as the free demo, achievements and the reaction from the developers when you try and obtain the unobtainable achievement via the console take a great part in making this game as appealing as it is.  I feel as though however for what it is, despite the quality, is highly overpriced- even when put on sale. A must buy when cheaper for those whom are the curious type.

												This is a story about a man named Stanley. As a story, there is no rich or innovative gameplay, you simply take the role of Stanley during a story about Stanley, narrated by someone who is decidedly not Stanley. Stanley's story is a good one. At times it can be cheerful, frightening, sad, and frustrating, but it is well-written and well thought out.I loved 'The Stanley Parable', but if you expect to compare it to another game on steam between five and fifteen dollars, you might come away with mixed feelings, just like some of the other reviewers have. If you purchase this title knowing that it's a story, I'm confident you won't regret it.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2014
												Groundbreaking, brilliant, an excellent narrative, non-linear, puzzle like adventure. Both the demo version and the game are worth playing since the two have different story-lines. The gameplay, through surprising, is a little lacking, through.The more you get daring with it, the more the Narrator, AI and interactivity feels alive. Whether you pursue or undergo the Stanley story, you will need some basic measure of imagination to make any part a whole and fill in the blank yourself to get a real gut-wrenching and complete experience. If you can feel and have even a silver of imagination regarding SF, supernatural or horror, then the story will be there, more clear, strong, and real than many indie exploration games. It won't disappoint you. [LOW SPOILERS] The only thing that makes the game interesting and keep you from feeling discouraged are the mysterious natures and different behaviors of the Narrator. Whatever or whoever you see it as, it is difficult to know if the character of The Narrator changes depending of your choices, or if they had already reached secret conspiracies, sentience, and/nor hopes and your choices just push it to reveal. That adds up to the mystery and keeps encouraging exploration and curiosity, to the point that it helped me accept not reaching a solid One True Ending and still feel a sense of completion.If you don't count yourself, there are three characters present and able to interact together, two of them being eloquent and lovable disembodied voices. Even the developers aka The Line, the Confusing Schedule and the whole office building can be relatively counted as a independent character. In that way, the Stanely Parable may be considered part RPG.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 28, 2013
												This might be my most glowing review yet. The Stanley Parable is probably the most philosophically important game made to date. It ask questions about story, narration, authority, and freedom. The narration is witty, piercing, and expertly delivered. It leaves you asking fundamental questions about the nature of almost everything you might take for granted in life, and does not attempt to alleviate this unease with comforting placebos. I recommend it to intellectual gamers, you know who you are, who play games, not to escape reality, but to approach it from a new perspective. It's not for those looking for a challenge or wanting something to zone out to. But, if you're willing to let The Stanley Parable shake you to the core, it will almost certyainly fulfill that promise.

content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
												The Stanley Parable is a game much in the same vein as Dear Esther or Gone Home in that you won't be fighting anything, you won't be really doing much of anything, but that's the point of the game. You'll get a few solid laughs out of the game and will find yourself playing through all of the possible outcomes, but don't expect to really have your mind blown or anything.It's fun while it lasts and does its best to offer critiques of modern society, gaming and life, but a lot of it feels a bit forced. If you haven't learned the morals found in the Stanley Parable yet this game will be amazing to you, but otherwise you'll just find yourself nodding in agreement.

It is a very "meta" game, but not in a negative way. It takes all the experience we learned in our years of gaming and just says "lol what are you doing". In a very fancy way of course, with one of the greatest narrators in video game history. And I have played a lot of videogames. The gameplay itself is rather thin, but it is an experiment and a story (ha!) that you can ONLY experience in a videogame and you should definitely not miss it. Absolute recommendation.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 15, 2014
												This is the story of a man named Stanley. Stanley has an adventure dictated by his good friend, the Narrator, a charming Brit with a dry sense of humour and a fondness of shattering the fourth wall. Stanley has free reign to as he desires. He may disobey the Narrator if he so chooses. Consequences may or may not apply. The Narrator may throw Stanley to the wolves, or save him via Deus Ex Machina. Literally anything could happen. Stanley could be subject to a huge mind control experiment, or may find himself at odds with the Stanley Parable Adventure Line, or may even visit a museum dedicated to the Stanley Parable, built on the ashes of the fourth wall. A thoughtful parody on the nature of choice, and whether it exists in video games, the Stanley Parable quickly and voilently alternates between goofy, charming endings, and endings that will give you nightmares for weeks to come. The Stanley Parable offers something for everyone.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 26, 2014
												Well well well, a game without combat? What's the point then, right? I mean, what good is a video game if we can't live out a not-so-deeply buried desire to murder people with a wide array of weapons, vehicles, and vehicles with weapons? I mean come on, nothing else is fun. I just simply cannot fathom how a game could possibly be called a game without shoving a sharp object into something squishy or sticking C4 and blasting with rockets what isn't squishy. I also don't know why people insist on playing games that make you think, and not with mind bending puzzles, but provocative subject matter. I don't play games to ponder the nature of existence! I play to mindlessly press as many buttons as I can, and to do so in a better order and timing than another player miles away that I'll never meet. I play to prove that I'm better than you!......what's this? This game is actually entertaining? No way. There is no way that a game set in an office building could possibly be fun until it catches fire and the aliens attack after I headshot all the zombies. And why am I playing as a white-collar nobody? I can't do anything but...push buttons.....push buttons........buuuuuuuttoooooonnnnnnssssss.........So, you made it through my horrid rant of satire, as you can probably guess, I LOVE THIS GAME. I'm so relieved to know that there are still devs out there who are trying new things without packaging it with something tired and overused. Every aspect of this game is the antithesis of what the big-wig empty suits in the mainstream developers' table think a good game makes. This game reminded me why I play games, to be ENTERTAINED, and by the gods above, does this game deliver. Okay okay, I'll be fair. The gameplay is almost non-existant. You walk, push buttons, and can crouch for seemingly no reason other than maybe another camera control. You can't even jump. But, are we here for action? Not really, we're here for comedy, we're here for surrealism (that doesn't reference a certain girl with a blue dress and a rabbit), and we're here for some new perspective. This perspective, however, can honestly hit a little too close to home. The game almost doesn't want you to play it, the main character speaks volumes of this. His job is pushing buttons, just like yours is while you play ANY game. His path is up to you, but the game loves pointing out that no matter what you choose to do, everything you decide on has been mapped out long beforehand, teaching the player that these notions of "freedom and choice" within games is essentially a delusional fantasy, that no matter what you choose, your options are predetermined, your actions well anticipated. Every game has walls, visible or no, they are there. And the narrator eats that up. Indeed, a game that subtley reminds you that you're deriving pleasure and a misplaced sense of achievement from some light thumb excercise is like a girlfriend casually bringing up her horse-hung/body-builder/rocket-scientist/senator ex-boyfriend while you're trying to get intimate. But somehow, I don't mind because that guy ended up in the electric chair for war crimes and hey, she's with me now, so win! Bottom line: There will be plenty of people who just won't understand this game, or what's supposed to be fun about it. These people have a poor sense of humor/irony, no self-awareness, and are xenophobic to mind-blowing proportions. It would be one thing to say it costs too much, or it's too short, or it's too repetitive, all these things are true to varying degrees. BUT! Anyone who says this game is "bad, horrible, boring, stupid, gay, pointless" or any other dismissively cynical criticism should be ignored. Only idiots will not enjoy this game, because idiots do not like being reminded that they are idiots. No, The Stanley Parable isn't very long, or lasting in replay value, but it's a great way to feel like somebody spiked the coffee in the employee lounge with a mild dose of LSD and Stephen Fry-esque wit.MMMM. PROS: Equal parts funny and provacative, a unique game with genuine character and an identity all it's ownCONS: A tad overpriced for some, especially since you'll probably play it for one weekend and only break it out when you want to psychologically profile a friend while you share a few laughsIf this game gets sequeled, I will buy it. If they call the sequel "Hubris" to better showcase the core concept, I'll buy a copy for me and every friend I have. That's right, a whole 3 copies.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2014
												It's impossible to describe what's interesting about the Stanley Parable without stealing its thunder. There's nothing really like it. This is a game for people who are intrigued by the idea of really *thinking* about why we play games. It's for the kind of person who likes talking about philosophy with their friends - and you'll want to talk about the Stanley Parable with your friends, too, if you're that kind of person.All of this makes the Stanley Parable sound very dry, but more often, it's hilarious, or confusing, or provocative. Sometimes, the Stanley Parable will make you feel bad about yourself for playing the Stanley Parable. Different people will find that different parts of the game affect them more personally, but any way you slice it, it's something special.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												EXA sat there beginning to question how to write a review of The Stanley Parable. "Was it a good game" he asked. He did enjoy his experience of The Stanley Parable, I mean he played two straight hours of it, non stop, and only had to stop, to write the review. But he questioned would others like to have the same experience, would others enjoy the game, would others read his review and based on his review, make a purchase. Was it important that he wrote a review. Then he began to realize, why was there a narration, its as if he was in The Stanley Parable himself, and the narrator began making his choices. EXA tried to deviate from the review. As he became conscious of the narrator, the narrator decided it was time to restart the review, again.EXA sat there beginning to question how to write a review of The Stanley Parable.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2015
												The Stanley Parable is a hilarious critique of one of the biggest issues when it comes to game design, the issued of forced player interaction being the only way to further progress the game. We've had hilariously awful cases like these such as the one in Call of Duty where you had to "Press F to Pay Respects". Seriously, who in the development studio thought that was a good idea? Space, time, everything in the game is literally frozen and nothing moves forward until you finally decide to press that one key on your keyboard. That kind of game design is cringeworthy and immersion breaking. Stanley Parable decides to have a laugh with it.Here, you can either do what the game tells you to do (well, what the narrator tells you) which results in short linear story that is ironic and self-aware, or you can go out of your way to troll the narrator and either outright refuse to do the things he tells you to do or do the complete opposite which results in hilarious writing and some absolutely bizarre locations and situations.Its only con is the short length and lack of content. It'll take you about 3 hours to get to experience everything the game has to offer. Whether that is worth the full price of $15 is up to you but it is definitely worth picking up on sale or in a bundle.Full review:


YouTube™ Video: The Stanley Parable (2013) - PC - Review 

			Views: 123		

			The Stanley Parable is a first person exploration game. You will play as Stanley, and you will not play as Stanley. You will follow a story, you will not follow a story.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2015
												The game is full of choices, many, many choices, and you will relive Stanley's life over and over again in one of the most mind-bogglingly hilarious meta games ever made.This is one of those games that you will want to show to your friends, and then they will want to show it to their friends, and suddenly all of these strangers are coming over to your house to play The Stanley Parable, drink beer, and roast chicken. No, seriously, this game has spawned literal potlucks at my house. Instead of watching the superbowl, people came over and drooled behind the glowing screen of my computer as they watched the next victim step up to play the plate and drown themselves in the world of Stanleys mind. "Oh," you and your companions will wonder, "What hallway will they go down this time? Will they find the closet? Will they escape? I wonder if they will just stand around doing nothing."  Then, when they finally discover the meaning of life, you watch as their reality crumbles into nothingness, a sheer endless point in space and time where nothing and everything revolves around Stanley. Then everyone argues about what Stanley is, and a war breaks out, and no one even touches the delcious marinated chicken you worked so hard on.Yes, as you dive into the stale corridors of Stanley's workplace ignoring the existance of delicious, cooked meat, your mind will wonder as you wander down hallways living the life of the stupendously wise and all-knowing Stanley. Will you "win?" Well, it all depends on what you believe is winning. For me, I took home in a closet and counted the dots on the ceiling. It was wonderful. I finally felt I had a purpose. Yes, you too can find purpose with The Stanley Parable. Download it now and instantly make your dark and depressing life brighter in these hard times.10/10 (Over 50 hours on record, mostly played offline so it's not recorded)

content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												This is one of my favorite games. The game presents you with choices and the narrator will tell which choice is the "correct" path. You can choose to follow his directions, or ignore them and go about your own way. There are so many directions you can go, and so many secrets. The narrator gets snarky if you ignore him and his lines will keep you laughing for a while. If you have doubts, there is a free demo that really shows what the game is like. There isn't any fighting or action. Just walking and listening to the narrator's comments. But trust me, it's worth it. Like other games, I would wait for a sale on this before buying. If you enjoy comedy and 4th wall breaking, you will love this game.A note for players: check out the broom closet after the meeting room and stay in there. 8/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 13, 2015
												The Stanley Parable is like that one crazy ex-girlfriend that left a mark on your life. Every now and then you can still hear the echoes of her nagging or condescending voice that gives you chills. You can still feel her trying to compress everything that you love, to drive out what makes you unique. The pressure and anxiety of having to deal with her every day was only intensified by the fact that you couldn't simply walk away. Things weren't that easy, they could never be that easy. She had her hooks sunk into you and all you could do was writhe, hoping that the pain would eventually end.And yet at the end of it all you wouldn't trade the experience for anything, because it taught you what true horror looks like. However a part of you wonders how things would be different if you didn't have that lasting scar on the back on your mind, the ever present sting of a wound that may never fully close. Sometimes you just stare off blankly and wonder how things got so chaotic, how things spiraled to where you are now. You wonder how many pills it would take to end it all, or maybe a small incision straight up your forearm. How long would take before the darkness consumes you and pulls you into the cold abyss? What would your final breath feel like?I believe I may have digressed. Great game, give it a shot.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 10, 2015
												 The Stanley Parable follows a letter cruncher who, one day, becomes unhinged at the drudgery of his existence and proceeds to murder every single human being within his workplace. Stanley comes-to staring at a computer monitor and the video game becomes navigating the hallucinations of his drifting, part lucid mindscape, narrating his own progression toward some self-appointed / meaningless objective in a somewhat sarcastic, yet deadpan tone.  You might be wondering, "Wow, these are the most bland hallucinations I've ever seen. How can you call walking around an immaculate / vacant office space a hallucination?" Well, considering Stanley's *actually* stepping over the dismembered corpses of coworkers and employers alike, ignoring the arterial spray that's painted the inside of most every cubicle; along with the entrails that he's ticker-taped down the corridors, smearing excrement into the carpet as he's gone, well... Anyway, Horror Game of the Year. Purchase it and recall to mind the context I've detailed for you for full effect.
